NEW NOVELS.
A PRIEST'S TRAG'EDY.
THE WMON AND PXST. By
GRAZmA DELEDDA. (Jonathan Cape. 6s. net.)
Miss Mary G. Steegmnnn's translation of Grazia Deledda's novel " La Madre " is excellently done, so far as smoothness and accuracy go. She has hardly succeeded, however, in reproducing the effect which Signora Deledda's stories achieve in their original tongue, especially in the dialogue, where, without using dialect excessively, the simple but passionate souls of the Sardinian villagers stand-vividly before the reader.
A translation, unless it be the work of a genius, seems to hang a tissue of alien mentality in front of simplicity like this which deadens its vibrations. This swift and tragic tale, the action of which is laid in the remote village of Aar in Sardinia, has three main characters: Paul the young priest, his old mother, and the well-to-do young woman Agnes who lives alone in the big house. Old Maria Elena has brought up her son to be a priest on her savings as a servant. He had grown up remote from the world, thinking only of the holy mys,teries, and, after his consecration, had been welcomed a9S a saint in his mother's native village, long benighted. There he had passed seven calm years, during which "he thought of himself as having already lived his life, as having known all it could offer, *-isery, humiliation, love, pleasure- and expiation; as having withdrawn from the world like some-old hermit, and waiting only for the Kingdom of God."
Instead, he was an innocent, young man of twenty-eight who suddenly was caught by the beauty of earthly passion. His mother, whose life he was, sits despair. ing in the presbytery as the story opens. The struggle comes to its climax and ends in the two days of the story's action. Having sworn to his mother on his return that night that he will not see Agnes again, Paul passes two nights and a day of torment. Very sldlfully Grazia Deledda shows him moving in silent agony against the background of village life, reading the Gospel over an . epileptic child, taking the viaticum to an old huntsman in his miountain hut, and counselling hisboysaeristan Antiochusan adorable character. There is a second meeting with Agnes, drawn with great power, in which the strength of the girl's single heart is grander than the weakness of a soul divided between love and conscience. She threatens to expose him at the early Mass. The Mass begins, and she is there. All three are in the little church: the spiritual conflict is intense. But Agnes falls kneeling at the altar rails, and the eyes of the old mother are darkened for ever. She had died of the grief and the terror that her son had overcome. It is a moving tragedy, but neither in English nor in Plrotestant England can such a tragedy make its fullest appeal.

Title: First National Book Sale In Britain
Full_text:
FIRST NATIONAL BOOK
SALE IN BRITAIN
-------0
AGREEMENT ON PRICES
The first " national book sale " to be held in Britain will start on February 16 and continue for 10 days until February 26. It has been organized by the Booksellers' Association and the Publishers' Association as "a joint effort towards greater trade prosperity."
Its main object wil be to enable booksellers to dispose of their less saleable stocks at the best possible prices, and publishers to sell off over-stocks. So far, 750 booksellers in 450 towns have agreed to take part, as also have 211 publishers.
The Booksellers' Association bas more than 2,000 members but there are said to be in this country fewer than 500 " pedigree " sellers-those who deal only in books. In London, which has about 36 " pedigree" sellers, about 100 bookselers will take part.
STORES REPRESENTED
Some of the larger firms which are also newsagents and stationers and have a big trade in fancy goods are not taking part, because, it is said, of difficu4ties in accountancy. On the other hand, many big stores with self-contained book departments will be pepresented.
An elaborate set of rules for the sale has been agreed. These provide that during the sale " participating bookseUers wil be permitted to offer, at any price not over twothirds of the published price, stocks of any title of which they have not ordered a copy during the last 12 months." Any publisher wi,l have the right to stipulate that none of his titles shal be included in the sale. For Publishers' over-stocks the sale price will be not more than 50 per cent. of the published price, but during an agreed period at the end of the sale the bookseller may fix his own price on these over-stocks to clear any unsold.
Since the war about 17,500 new titles and reprints have been published annually, and last. year the total rose to more than 19,000. This may be regarded as a healthy sign of activity in the world of letters, but it also adds to the bookseller's constant problem of selecting stock and being left with unsold c:opies that represent locked-up capital.
BY THE ARMFUL
The annual book sale has become a wellestablished event in Australia; in 1953 one firm sold 80,000 books in 10 days, many customers buying books by the armful. In Sweden the annual book sale lasts a montn and it is reported that 90 per cent. of the bargains offered are sold.
The organizers of the sale-a joint committee of booksellers and publishers, with Mr. Thomas Joy as chairman-feel confident that there is now enough support and enthusiasm within the trade to ensure success.

Mr. Conal O'Riordan's " Soldier Born" was generally hailed as a remarkable historical noveL Its successor, which carries on the story of young David Quinn, is in every way as fine. All the old characters who made so vivid an appearance in the former book, includig the Regent and his daughter, Princess Charlotte, are in this. But there are perhaps fewer of the light moments which relxieved the grimness of the record of David Quinn's youth, and the Waterloo episode is as terrible as any anti-war propagandist could desire. One of Mr. O'Riordan's best qualities as a novelist is undoubtedly his power of making his minor characters live. Lady Quinn, for example, David's young stepmothler, is as surely alive^as Tony Dazincourt, his bosom friend, though her appearances are few and short. Her sentiments regarding her stepson are never once defined, or even hinted at, but they are perfectly clear. There is, apparently, to be another volume devoted to David Quinn, and even those not commonly enamoured of sequels will agree that it is worth while hearing more of him.
Mr. Sinclair Lewis is in holiday mood. It is hardly a novel that he gives us, since i he does no more than record the conversation of Mr. Lowell Schmaltz in a monologue of 250 pages. That gentleman, a citizen of Zenith, is a close business acI quaintance of our old friend Mr. George F. Babbitt;' and the fact is a sufficiently clear indication of the kind of satire Mr. Lewis achieves. "Read widely, think Iscientifically, speak briefly, and sell the goods ! " expresses the sum of wisdom and philosophy for the unfortunate Mr. Schmaltz (who had known President Coolidge in his youth), who pours out a stream of commonplaces and stupidities upon a great variety of American topics. It is all quite amusing and instructive, though rather too facile for a writer of Mr. Lewis's distinction.
Miss Willa Cather's new novel is written on the theme of the hostility which a woman may feel for the man with whom she is yet deeply in love. Love and hate are strangely and vigorously united in the heart of Myra Henshawe for her husband, and in contrast are the tolerance and admiration of the latter, devoted nurse in her fatal illness, in the course of which she turns on Iim and, bitterly regretting her marriage, denounces him in terrible words. It is a painful tale with its depressing view of the seemingly inevitable inconsistencies and regrets of love, but it is finely told.
Mr. Powys's short stories are in the main idyllic tales of the countryside, always charming and often fanciful. Many have a satisfactory moral, as' when a new squire, who is very proud of the uniqueness of his name, banishes the harmlessvillage lunatic to an asylum, only to find that, when the lunatic dies, on his tombstone is plainly written the same name as that of the squire. The idyll does not, of course, exclude tragedy, and even when Mr. Povys is most light and amusing there is a weight of meaning behind his fable. But perhaps it is the mixture of the remote and the homely in Mr. Powys's fantasy which is most striking in these stories.

Title: New Novels

NEW NOVELS
NAPOLEONIC EUROPE
THE COURT OF FAIR MAIDENS. BY WIL-
HELM SPEYER. Translated by PHYLis and TREVOR BLEwTrT. .Gollancz. 8s. 6d.
This is a charming and vividly realized picture of the Court of one of the smallest of the German States of the Rhineland at the time of the First Coalition against Napoleon. In the early part of the year 1805 two policies were being urged upon Duke Johann Christoph, the ruler of the little Duchy of Kreu-Reuthe. One policy, of which the chief spokesman was the excessively statesmanlike Chancellor, Freiherr vonI Ungemach, favoured a definite alliance with the Emperor; the other, Which was urged by the Duke's confidential adviser, the guarded and far-seeing Dr. Voss, had its basis in dependence upon the Coalition Powers. Both sides to the diplomatic dispute sought to further their ends through the marriage of one of the "fair maidens" of the Court. To the proposed marriage of the Duke's sister Fedora with a Russian Grand Duke, cousin to the Tsar, the French party replied with a suggested marriage between Ulrike, the daughter of Count Murray, and the most sensible and practical of Napoleon's generals, the thoroughly likeable d'Orguerre.
The author has elaborated a pretty and graceful pattern of love and diplomacy in the telling of the tale. It is a remarkably well informed piece of work, done with a good eye for the perspective of history and bearing its learning lightly. The sentiment for the most part rings true enough, and the philosophical Voss and the hearty, dissolute, tyrannically benevolent Johann Christoph are both fine and individual portraits.
THE EMOTIONAL JOURNEY. By W. B.
MAXNVELL. Hutchinson. 7s. 6d.
This is the second volume of the trilogy begun with "Tudor Green," and to be completed by a novel called "Our Little. Lives," under the general title of " Men and Women." What Mr. Maxwell calls the " basic idea " of his scheme is, in our own words, to provide a sort of general picture of the group of people that comes. under his observation, some members being important enough to come into the foreground, others, it may be, having little or no direct relation with them, taking their place only as background. These subsidiary figures are carefully drawn. If we ch6ose to forget the composition- as a whole, we may turn our attention to them and realize that their lives, also, might be used as the subject for.a full-sized canvas. But what we learn of them here has no influence on the development of the principals, and provides no material for any social theory.
In " The Emotional Journey " we move from the suburban circumference of " Tudor Green"' to the focus of London life, and the characters whose story is definitely interrelated are all members of that literary world which Mr. Maxwell knows so well. There is, of course, a developing story, reasonably intricate, -moving towards a crisis, involving the lives of the literary characters and, in addition, two women. Mr. Maxwell's inventive imagination shows no sign of flagging, nor his open-eyed, kindly interest in contemporary men and women.
FEAR IN THE HEART. By CONSTANCE
MALLESON. Collins. 7s. 6d.
This is a story of an unhappy love affair between Hilary Barnes, a war-scarred artist whose powers have left him, and Lady Mallory, whose young husband was killed in the War. Art and books, modern farming, the life of t'ie Somerset countryside and the revolutionary existence of artists in Paris are all discussed with knowledge. delicacy, and comprehension; and the scenes descriptive of the life of the ancient castle and the unspoilt village are charming.
Lady Constance observes very clearly and manages to convey.with-lyric intensity what she hag observed, whether it is the games of. a child, the. pastoral beauty of cider-making, or the fragile beauty of Japanese colour-prints. This is :a book that will not appeal to readers who want high lights and thrills, but to those who care for the quieter, more subtle excitements.

Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS MAN AND HIS FREEDOM
BURMESE SILVER. By EDVA.RD THOMP- I
SON. Faber and Faber. 7s. 6d.
NOT WITH ME. By MARJORIE DEANS.
Gollancz. 7s. 6d.
No ESCAPE. By RANDALL S\VINGLER.
Chatto and Windus. 7s. 6d.
WAR ON SATURDAY WEEK. By RUTH
ADAM. Chapman and Hall. 7s. 6d.
THE VIRGIN KING. By FRANCIS WATSON.
Appleton-Century. 7s. 6d.
" Post-War," " pre-War," " during the Great War "-automatically the mind classifies and labels, insistent on its belief that before it can assess a modern man or an experience or even a fictitious story each must be brought into relation to what still seems a period of demarcation, almost of severance. Involuntarily the eye travels along the horizontal line that brings us closer to 1914 or further from it. Into the happy days before the War we peer incredulously, almost with suspicion, conscious all the time of that which follows; and it is only when the movement is vertical, when a man grows up and matures instcad of merely growing older, that this obsession with time may be ignored. In "Burmese Silver" Mr. Thompson has described such a man. As he sails farther and farther up the Chindwin on his way to see, after 30 years, the friend who was translated, first so shamefully and then so fantastically, from a humble post in the Indian Civil Service to a Burmese raj, Clive Powell has put the ordinary behind him. After a respectable though not particularly distinguished career he is free to spend the last year of his life as he pleases. The birds, the confident natives, the wild, flamboyant forests, the mountains up towards China, everything adds to his sense of remoteness and content. The peculiar problems of this mountain kingdom, ruled by a Raja whose savage unhappiness alone differentiates him from a potentate in Mr. Arliss's Eastern manner, fill him with no more than a faint melancholv. Though he may still feel impelled to help, these, like everything else now, lie outside him. The mood is quickened as the exigencies of Mr. Thompson's romantic plot warm the book into action, but it is essentially a mood of contemplation, gazing gravely and tenderly upon a multifarious existence.
A CONVERT TO ROME
The vicar in "Not With Me" is permitted no such withdrawal into himself. He, too, has reached an age when the external world seems less important than that of the spirit, but the problems of an Anglican clergyman have a way of associating themselves mercilessly with everyday existence. The holiday in Italy was undertaken in an attempt to recapture some of the religious delight of his youth; it ended in his decision to enter the Roman Church. On his return to England the concrete obstacles in his way became more and more apparent. Mloney itself was only a secondarv consideration, although to leave the priesthood meant giving up his sole income. But to seem to fail his wife after 25 years, to tell his parishioners that he no longer believed what he had always taught them-seen at close quarters, as Miss Deans lets us see them, quietly and without hysteria, these demand strength as well as purpose to set them aside. The main theme is continued into several minor episodes, into the more or less ordinary lives of an ordinary family. In a book so level-headed as this, romantic makeshifts are apt to appear more false than usual. The incident of the young man who squandered his inheritance on six months among the " countv " may be fact, but one doubts if it is truth, and the deroitenletlIt, though a convenience for the author, strikes the reader as dangerously arbitrary.
So far we have been dealing with what are, after all, civil emergencies. In " No Escape " Mr. Randall Swingler effects the transition from the individual and private life to the individual and war. He makes, at first, a beautiful pattern, a fine web of sensation and thought into which all who have to do with Longwood House, poised so austerely above its park and the lake where the swans nest, have spun their threads. There is one memorable scene, when the delicate, sensitive boy goes swimming and has his first experience of class enmity; and there are lesser glimpses of the cold, formal mother, the shadowy, elegant, useless father, the family at the rectory and the inarticulate, poeticallv perceived villagers. Then gradually, sadly, the pattern recedes, the lovers come into prominence, and the summer brings in war. The writing is imaginative and assured, and in spite of the descent from the exquisite general statement to the more ordinary particular it is a distinguished first novel.
THE " YELLOW SHIRTS"
Whereas war enters Mr. Swingler's book as something factual but arbitrary, it is present in Miss Adam's "War on Saturday Weck " from the start. In yet another English rectory four children are intermittently aware of the Great War in progress somewhere beyond the garden walls. As they grow up, choosing one the Air Force, another journalism, another the Communist faith, and the fourth marriage with a peaceable young schoolmaster, all share with the rest of the world a feeling of suspense that cannot fail to precipitate another war. They expect war, and it comes, a conflict between the Fascist nations and those professing Communism, into which England is bound to enter if she is to preserve some measure of democracy at home. The personal stories are inclined to be dull, once we are done with the childhood scenes;
and the principal interest of the book is to be found in its picture of the middle classes powerless to prevent a war they hate and dread while the extremists of both right and left are sustained by convictions as powerful as they are narrow.
If the preceding novels approach war and class conflict from the angle of painful reality, Mr. Watson's " The Virgin King " launches out into a grotesque satire on dictatorships in Central Europe. The son of an English magnatc wanders through the wrong door in an aeroplane flying over Gorboduchy, where the hermit of Prague may still be found firing pensive axioms at the niece of King Gorboduc, and steps into mid-air to become the central figure in the revival of the monarchy. The humour is a little in the manner of Mr. Branch Cabell, jesting at sense and sexuality, and turning to comic account the yellow shirts of a brand-new political party. It is an elegant, well-informed comedy, given at times to a rather academic wit, and just sufficiently fanciful to conceal the pains the author has taken with his politics.

Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS
MR. GALSWORTHY'S
SEQUEL
Among new novels are FLOWERING WILDERNESS, by John Galsworthy (Heinemann, 7s. 6d. r4-t); and FIRST NIGHT, by Lorna Rea (Heinemann, 7s. 6d. net).
Mr. John Galsworthy has been at considerable pains in some of his more recent novels to show his understanding of the spirit of modern youth. In his new book modern youth has very little to say. Miss Elizabeth, or " Dinny," Cherrell (whom Mr. Galsworthy's regular readers will remember in " Maid in Waiting," to which the new book is a sequel) was not really nodern, like Fleur Mont, who also is to be met again in these pages. She talked very brightly, and she was prepared (not without other excuse than mere haste) to give herself to her lover before marriage; but one reason why she will rouse more interest and sympathy than some others among Mr. Galsworthy's heroines is that she is of no particular period. Not mnodernity but womanhood exposes her to the sufferings inflicted upon her by a traditional ideal which is here represented as losing its hold but still strong enough to assert itself. Dinny's lover, Wilfred Desert (the queer fellow and poet who had once manifested strictly dishonourable intentions to Fleur Mont), had done something which let England down in the East. It might not have mattered much anywhere else; but it was a blow at British prestige in Islam; and therefore unpardonable. Moreover, he went and did something even worse: he wrote, and published, a marvellous poem explaining it all. Others besides the " pukka sahibs " could not forgive that. Yet Dinny could and would have defied the sahibs and her family and friends and all, and have stuck to her Wilfred if it had not been that Wilfred himself was not wholehearted in his own support. How he thought and felt about his past conduct and'his future life is shown by Mr. Galsworthy with the best of his skill and power, and the unhappy end of the tale is felt to be inevitable. The book is rich in emotion, and sees deep into the human heart.
One has always wondered what would happen if a dramatic critic could think of nothing to say before his paper went to press; and that is what very nearly happened to Mr. Evan Jones, who did the film and dramatic criticism for the Chatterer, besides the " Cosy Corner " on Fridays. But this is to begin at the wrong end of Mrs. Rea's book, which, starting with Mrs. Mackenzie in apron and feathered hat while she removes the carpet covers from the Duchess of York's Theatre, takes us through a few hours of hopes, fears, love, and indigestion to the decline and fall of Mr. Williams's play and the final re-covering of the carpets. By the time the lights are out we know a great deal about managers, producers, actors, actresses, and critics, and have sympathized with the Collins family in their rather Rabelaisian silver wedding celebrations. Mrs. Rea manages to indicate the strength and weakness of Cecil Williams's play very convincingly. We leave him comforted by the feeling that to have had a play produced at all is something and, though the thought is disloyal and must be suppressed if possible, that Elaine is no such great loss after all.

Author: Baddiel, David
Title: 'What am I doing owning a copy of Make Your Own Fishing Tackle?'
Full_text:
ook,
David Baddiel fWhat am I doing owning a copy of Kake Your Own Fishing Tackle?1
WHAT DO ADOLF HITLER, MARY Whitehouse, Jimmy Greaves and Dick Emery have in common? Probably quite a lot if you do enough research, but the immediate answer is that all of them coexist quite happily up on my bookshelves. Moreover, they share a heritage particularly common on my bookshelves, which is that I have no memory of how they got there. Ooh You Were Awful ...But I Like You — the life story of Dick Emery as told to his — count 'em — sixth wife, Fay Hillier — has a reduced sticker from a shop called The Works on it (£15.99 down to £10, then to a further £4.99) and I do have a very vague memory of once being in The Works looking at remaindered books; but actually taking this one to the till, getting the fiver out of my wallet, and rushing home to read Fay's superbly detailed biog of the great man (if a little cursory, perhaps, on the subject of Dick's other five wives) — that's gone. Similarly, I noticed Jimmy Greaves's The Heart of The Game sitting by itself — as if picked out in a Waterstone's recommendation — on my shelves last week, but — perhaps like Jimmy in his drinking days — have no memory of how exactly it ended up there. The Mary Whitehouse book is a tome entitled Whatever Happened to Sex? I'd assumed it was a cri de coeur about the author's personal life, the answer to which, I have to say, is provided by the photo of Mary on the back — but it is, in fact, a learned argument against the permissive society, which, judging from the state of the cover, I rushed out and bought immediately on its publication in 1977, presumably in between buying a new protractor and Never Mind the Bollocks. But I have no memory of doing so. Hitler is a slightly different kettle offish, as I do remember buying most of my Nazi/ Holocaust books, some of which I've had for a while, others that came during the writing of my last novel, set during the war — but what I don't remember is the moment at which these went beyond the standard legal requirement for a North London Jew and became a full-on Hitler/Holocaust library section. Surely there was a moment when I thought: "Hold on... is this becoming a bit creepy? Am I going to be contacted any minute by Stormfront's book club?" But clearly not. It's one of the functions, I think, of being a bit bookish. The fact is, I buy a lot of books, on impulse, I get sent a lot of books, and I hardly ever throw out books — taking the Nazi
A Uf r% rt
hangover a stage further, a part of me feels it's only one step away from book-burning although, actually, I think organising one of those for the Hitler section may be not a bad thing. The trouble is, as one ages, of course, you can't remember why you ever bought half of them. And worse still, you realise that the assumption behind keeping all these books — that you will get round to reading them al one day — is, with time, looking shaky. Will I ever get beyond, for example, just flicking through the photos in Backstage Passes, the biography of Angie Bowie (described as "wickedly funny" by the Atlanta Journal And Constitution)? How heartbreakingly hopefu was it of me to buy Pier Paolo Pasolini's Ragazzi di vita, in the belief that I would one day read it in the original Italian? What am I doing owning a copy of W. E Davies's Make Your Own Fishing Tackle? And presiding over them all, the King, of course, of the Great Unread, The Dauphin of "I'm Definitely Going to Do It One Day", my
much-thumbed, and much put-down, copy of Swann's Way, the first volume of A la recherche du temps perdu. It's a great thing, though. When bored, I can browse through my shelves like a lucky dip. Some books serve as biography, reminding me of mental things about my youth — I have a copy of Mary Cadogan and Patricia Craig's You're A Brick, Angela! (The Girls' Story 1839-1985) because, when I was 11,1 was the youngest member — by about 80 years — ofa society called The Old Boys Book Club, to which Mary (not so sure about Patricia) was also affiliated. And some, like the aforementioned, are just mental. Flicking through Mary Whitehouse's book now I notice a sentence that begins "Alice Cooper, the male 'pop star' is ..." as if the phrase pop star was just some ridiculous affectation, held in quarantine away from Mary's nose by the inverted commas. This makes me want to read the whole thing. I won't, of course. But I won't throw it out either.

Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS
MR. EDMUND BLUNDEN IN
FLANDERS
Among new novels are WE'LL SHWFr OuR GROUND, OR Two ON A TOUR, by Edmund Blunden and Sylva Norman (Cobden-Sanderson, 7s. 6d. net); and TiE MIDSHIPMAID, by Ian Hay (Hodder and Stoughton, 7s. 6d. net).
Duncan and Chloe went to Cassel in Flanders, which was for a certain time far more familiar in our ears and is now being forgotten. At least, Duncan went there on a writing and sketching mission, and Chloe, to whom he had just said good-bye in London, arrived on his heels. Duncan was given to brooding upon the War, whose memories at once fascinated and repelled him, and brooding in a manner which sometimes recalls Mr. Edmund Blunden. Chloe seems to have felt a similar fascination and repulsion for. Duncan; at any rate, her words expressed the repulsion and her actions the fascination. Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS
THE SHOWMEN'S WORLD
CROCUS. By NEIL BELL. Collins. 8s. 6d.
Mr. Neil Bell gives us a full-blooded tale of the showmen's world of yesterday, not sparing its cruclties and coarseness, but winning our sympathy for vital characters, and keeping a long story moving briskly to its end. " Crocus " is the rather idyllic name given in the fairs to the quackdoctor (or " croakus "), .and the gipsy " Professor" Louis Delfontaine is a magnificent specimen of his tribe, persuasive, brutally ambitious and yet capable of kindly feelings, which he lavishes on an outcast baby, born one night almost within the canvas walls of his travelling home, and adopted by him as his own child. Jethro Delfontaine divides the interest of the story with his turbulent father. He grows up to be a great boxer, for no attempts at giving him a gentlemanly education can keep him from returning to the lure of the booths; and while the Professor ascends from the flashboard and the naphthalampsto become first a respectable herbalist, and then a wealthy exploiter of patent medicines, Jethro feels he must go back to the road. The episodes of his pugilistic career contain some of the best fights in fiction since " Rodney Stone."'
THE SPRING HOUSE. By LADY CYNTHIA
ASQUITH. Michael Joseph. 7s. 6d.
Lady Cynthia Asquith's first novel is interesting, amusing in parts, and very competent, making one feel that with another choice of subject she could do very well indeed. The central figure of her story is a girl who, married very young to a rather dull husband of whom she has seen little, has had an undeveloped emotional life. She is sufficiently beautiful to have many admirers, and intelligent enough to have many friends as well; but she has not enough self-confidence to enable her to deal satisfactorily with either.
She is far from being the only young woman for whom the War has broken up hatural family Jife; but her husband, unlike others, is in no danger, and her sense of loyalty to him, though present, is not overbearing; it allows her to entertain a court of young men whom she .cannot bear to dismiss entirely by denying them all hope. This state of affairs continues until John Marlowe, a friend of her brother, appears and falls as violently in love with her as she with him. Then, rather to her own surprise, scruples arise; she is compelled to send him back to France-and to his death-disbelieving in her love. in obedience to what she believes would be the standards of her mother and husband. This decision is a deep tragedy to her, which only gains in bitterness from the later discovery that neither husband nor mother has upheld those standards.
WHITEOAK HARVEST. By MAZO DE LA
ROCHE. Macmillan. 7s. 6d.
With unflagging vigour and interest Miss de la Roche presents a further chapter in the lives of that well-known Canadian family, the Whiteoaks of Jalna. This time her harvest is one of old sins and weaknesses, of warring wives and husbands who are not strictly faithful. She does not involve anyone in hopeless tragedy or lifelong regret, indeed she reconciles families and rescues a child or two from distress of one kind or another, but she is not going to pretend that a single member of her large caste is entirely splendid. The picture is as carefully composed as usual and the tempestuous brothers are well differentiated.
The very ordinary Canadian problem of mixed religions crops up, this time a. younger brother being taken with a rather sentimental conception of himself as a monk in a cell, with a child to be named for him one day, by the girl he is giving up. But his resolution fails him and it is the girl who finds her vocation in a convent. Horses are an important interest for all true Whiteoaks, even the small girl of four demanding to jump gates and ditches and showing no fear in the stables.
THE BIG MONEY. By JoHN' Dos PASSOS.
Constable. 7s. 6d.
The third volume of Mr. Dos Passos's presentation of twentieth-century America deals with the decade 1919-29. Some. new characters appear; more are carried on from the preceding books, together with the documentary " news-reels," the personal " camera eye," and the short biographies of actual Americans of outstanding social significance. Save for a few rather furtive " radicals," the imagined characters almost all partake in some degree of the common if unstable prosperity of these years, and one might, surveying their rather monotonously riotous behaviour with inevitable distaste, be inclined charitably to deem them merely as having too much money, were it not so evidently the author's conviction that people without it are not, on the whole, any more admirable.
One cannot accept this portrayal as more than a partial picture, omitting, in its harsh photographic realism, all too much of the colour and beauty inherent even in everyday living. But for all that Mr. Dos Passos must be acknowledged as one of the most vigorous and vital of contemporary American novelists, and his new volume in its variety and sensational immediacy of detail as compulsive and, within its limits, authentic a piece of writing as he has yet published.

A POST-WAR DRAMA.
SECRET HIWvESi,. By DOROTHY Pnncr-
vAL. (Heinemarnn. 7s. 6d. net.)
Miss Percival wrote a first novel, "Footsteps," which showed promise.. Her second, " Secret Harvest," both ,i promise ahad in achievement, shows a great advance. She can write simply and directly. She has A sense of character. She can understand men as well as women. She does not seem, like so many novelists, to get her kriowledge-at second hand. Above all, she has a genuine sense of the drama of character, and she allows nothing 'to interfere with her dramna. It is th'is simplicity and. singloness of purpose i.nthe construction of her'book which is its most interesting quality.

Among new novels are A MAx NAMED LuRE, by March Cost (Collins, 7s. 6d. net); and PEKING PICXIc, by Ann Bridge (Chatto and Windus, 7s. 6d. net).
The heroine of M%iss March Cost's romantic or spiritual fantasy is both delightful and unusual. Phoebe-Ann is one of those child-like women whose eagerness is all the more poignant because they are destined to die young. But Miss Cost has realized that loveliness is as elusive as it is mortal, that it can be best glunpsed indeed in the unconscious conflict between opposites. Phoebe-Ann, in fact, is the innocently spoiled daughter of an American millionaire, an absurd, doting fatlher, and her accent is really impossible. But M%iss Cost, wve think, succeeds in her daring reality and we share wvitlh Mlr. Vincent, the erninent London surgeon, who falls in love with Phoebe-Ann, the torment of fascination and imaginative distraction. In her attempt to wrest the mystery from pain and contradiction, Miss Cost gives a poignant yet dramatic turn to her story. Despite all his skill and desperate efforts to save her life by an operation Mr. Vincent fails and Phoebe-Ann dies from shock. Thereafter the stoiy is worked out upon an imaginative plane. Years later, as he sits alone upon a winter's evening in his room at Cavendish Square, ir. Vincent finds himself in the mysterious Fourth Dimension. Past and present intermingle ; lie is aware both of the eighteenth century, with its thronging gaieties, and the immediacy of the twentiethl century: and through his fantasy hurries the beckoning, elusive figure of Phoebe-Ann. Miss Cost adventures safely in a world of imaginative longing which many writers have explored, but she has an original touch of her own.
Aliss Bridge has written a first novel which seems to have spruhg fully armed from her head witlh none of a first novel's drawbacks. Her scene is set in Peking and its environs, where a party of Legation people, civil and miitary, plan to camp for a week-end in a famous temple,
in spite of rumours of bandits. Here I and later in another temple where they are held prisoners for a few nerve-racking hours by the bandits, emotions ripen fast. Judith, the " singing Kuniang," takes Derek withl all his faults and charm - Annette proves the fortune that the bonze had given her, " Enlightemuent shall escape her, but death enlightens all "; Laura and Vinstead experience the lateflowering love wvhich "is apt to be a slow and painful consuming of habit, reason, and w ill in deep smoildering combustion," but with them is controlled and put aside. Among them, but far above them moves the perfect maid Hubbard, raging coquette among the English and Amencan soldiers at the " Y," and entirely mistress of any situation, treatinu China as a negligible quantity-a de'ightful creation.

As soon as Sir Maurice Audley, scapegrace of fashion and yoting squire of Aldrewood, who has only got to look at a girl and she drops—plum—at his feet, like a shot bird, as soon as his - attendant satellites and foreign women and motor-cars break in on Christopher Elwin’s forest hermitage, peace and innocence and most of the interest goes out of Rita’s hew " story, Jm—Aur.-Alone (Stanley Paul, 6s.). Sir Maurice is a sophisticated serpent— World,, flesh, and devil in one. He spoils-a promising and bizarre situation; sows discord and melodrama. Before his coming the happy family consisted of an esoteric old friend, Maitre Jouvence (out of “ Calvary ”), who signs a cryptic little note, sans “ carte du pays,” and to whom at last we bid farewell on the verge of the Sahara; a young Sir Galahad, Jocelin Knightrider, escaped by a miracle out of the, nets of a pompous, bigot, Father John ; a somewhat sententious old recluse who is a mine of storied lore and wields the secret countersign of the Great God Pan, and, above all, his adopted grand-daughter, Jill—in. a sunbonnet that shades, but cannot conceal, her burnished locks and rose and cream. Jill is a foundling, with blue blood manifest in wrist and arched ankle. Rube is her gipsy foster-brother. And when Prospero breaths the word of terror into this Caliban’s ear and the little woodland circle, with all due pagan rites, buries ,a young fawn beneath Pan’s oak, romance thickens. But Rita’s Prospefo is not a practise! match-maker. Not until Rube shows signs of the satyr, and Jocelin has turned sentimental, and Sir Maurice proves himself so .steeped in vice as to ask a kiss of Jill, does he realize the kind of world we live in. Then poor Jill (by no means a shot bird) is packed off to Avalon, to the Home of the Sacred Heart,and Mere AngSlique. To say that not one of these characters is real—not even Lady Vi, who makes Jocelin drink champagne at lunch—is not to say that their story has failed. But then, not one of them is quite unreal—»ot even Pan. They dwell in that vast vague region lying between fact and fiction. They resemble one’s neighbours seen in a pageant—dressed up, and unmistakably conscious of it. But this is not Mrs. Humphreys’s first novel, and she knows far better than we can tell her what her large circle expects of her fancy and her pen.
" THE ORLEY TRADITION.”
Mr. Ralph Straus is now in the agreeable condition (for novelists) known as “rising.” His work in “ The Orley Tradition ” (Methuen, 6s.), a Kentish" story, carries forward the promise already discerned in “ The Little God’s Drum,” although in the actual writing, as in the apparent absence of plot, there seem to be signs here and. there of hesitation and immaturity. But the reader will read on, not, we think, without occasional questionings, but with a consciousness of entertainment increasing all the time. The man who often

in a story 'is in the world ; can never be
not the easiest task to secure it faithfully merely an exercise in mental agility. Mr. Straus gives us something better than this.
Here, though it is soon perceived that the “ Orley tradition ” and mental agility are poles asunder, Mrs. Damson—the notable figure who serves for chorus with her “ famous remarks”—supplies the want very neatly. She has » great deal more of the. quality, for instance, than the showy, intriguing, almost ruffianly Mrs. Adderson. Mrs. Damson was only the keeper of the village shop. But she had expansive ideas about'business, and to her the personality of Lord Orley’s son John, as she watched it from his birth, gilded life with all tiie rapture of indefinite promise. Was that promise to be foiled either by Fate or by Mrs. Adderson ? John, the athlete, was in sad case
when his physical agility met with a sudden, nearly fatal, check. And what could he do With his wits t Sheer boredom seemed likely to drive him into the arms of the . adventuress for good and all. After all, he could do pretty well as he pleased. Nobody wanted to interfere at any particular moment, yet nobody wanted him to drift into a silly, sordid entanglement, and John was very susceptible, very human. At last sheer English common sense came to the rescue; and he found his salvation in Marjory Grant, who was no mere afterthought. Marjory belongs to the happy time of childhood wherein, by the drilling of his own “ Ariny,” John has evolved his own philosophy. The fact that Mr. Straus has deftly woven, these strands is all to his credit; his lesser characters, especially Mr. Outing, are brilliantly drawn ; and of the whole we feel bound to say that while the touch given is light, the impression left is considerable.
“THE GATES OF DOOM.”

The book opens well with a most melodramatic contest between the hero and a ruined rske, “ Guineas v. Girl,” and the situation develops apace. Its central figure is a great landowner, strong, popular, magnanimous, who lives with his widowed sister, Sally Bryce. It should perhaps be stated at once that his estate is in Virginia, not in England; but the story is not distinctively or oppressively American. Though Owen Randolph is the central figure, it is his nephew, Richard Bryce, who is the moving cause of all the trouble. A young man, fresh from eight years’ sojourn in Paris, he returns an artistic decadent and artificial egoist of the extremest type. His keen interest in the “ dark yet radiant magic that lurks ” in the mysterious perversities of femininity leads him to woo and betray a trusting, loving girl—a young cousin of Owen’s. Oast off by the voluptuous Richard, she is saved from despair, wooed, and honestly won by Owen. But her first-born child, she knows, will be Richard’s, not Owen’s. She dreads confession, while Owen, knowing the truth, expects it. And this uncomfortable situation, which could in a moment be resolved by a frank edairdssemeni, extends over a large part of the book. This is a tactical mistake, and the burden of it is hardly borne successfully by the author. But her resource in incident and character does much to redeem it.

NEW NOVELS.
THE HUMOUR OF IT.
RICHARD TalumpHAwT. By W. PETr
RIDGE. .(Methuen. 7s. 6d. net).
This story opens in a house in Bayswater, scene Richard Maynard's birthday party. Comes the news that Richard's father has absconded and the family is ruined. But Mr. Pett Ridge has no space for tragic emotion. Mrs. Maynard receives the news with unexpected calmness, almost, one would. say, with a twinkle in her eye, while it is not until later that we are let into the secret. She had known all along that the crash was* coming. So with this neat joke Mr. Pett Ridge disposes of the incident. A. little later the family, living now in poverty, with no money for the smallest amusement, recollects that before the crash came a box had been bought for Drury Lane. The ticket was left behind the clock in the dining-room in the old house. It may still be there. But how to. get, past the jealous caretakers 2 Richard solves the difficulty by borrowing a hurdy-gurdy and a monkey, impersonating the organ-grinder, getting into the kitchen on the plea of cold, and letting the monkey escape. It is a piece of elaborate humour. Mr. Kipling wrote one of his most riotous and amusing stories on this theme, but Mr. Pett Ridge wastes no words on making it funny. He uses it simply to get the ticket.
When Richard gets at last into the draper's shop he finds himself under a head clerk who warns him that he will never allow theatres mentioned in his *presence. Time passes and the head clerk is dismissed that Richard may take his place. Some writers might have touched on Richard's remorse, some on the pathos of an elderly man thrown aside when his usefelness is done, some on the wickedness of our social system. Not so Mr. Pett Ridge; all the dismissed clerk says is:
Knew all along you'd be the innocent cause of me getting the sack.... But I bear you no grudge, and fortunately I've recently become engaged to a lady who, dances at the Alhambra, so that I shan't have to look out for a fresh job.
No one else wouUl dare to do tivett, and, in fact, Mr. Pett Ridge has no right to do it. This is the spirit" however, in which he takes us through a quarter of a century of Richard's life. Even when he meanly jilts his employer's daughter; to whom he is secretly engaged, rather than lose his job, the incident is finished and put aside with a joke. Indeed, it comes almost as & shock when we find no joke to take away the tragedy of the death -of. Richard's wife. Richard exclaims " It's damned hard," and that is the only piece of real emotion.

Author: J. S.
Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS
MR. WELLS'S FANTASY
STAR BEGOTTEN. By H. G. WELLS. Chatto
and Windus. 6s.
NOTHING Is SAFE. By E. M. DELAFIELD.
Macmillan. 7s. 6d.
RosE FORBES. By GEORGE BUCHANAN.
Constable. 7s. 6d.
THE WIND FROm THE MOUNTAIN. By
TRYGV'E GULBRANSSEN. Translated by
NAOMI WALFORD. Thornton Butterworth. 7s. 6d.
THEY CROSSED THE REEF. By W. ToWN-
END. Chapman and Hall. 7s. 6d.
Much of thc criticism of the world we live in is directed against political systems, when it might be wiser to ask if we, being as we are, really deserve the Utopias we ask for. A change of heart is harder to accomplish than a change of government, and yet Utopia will always be more than a question of material improvements. When men are less selfish, less frivolous and less fearful, Utopia may come of its own accord, beyond the dreams of the most idealistic Communist. Thus it is dissatisfaction with lives rather than with politics that we ought first to encourage, and when we find a novel that is critical instead of smoothly acquiescent we can only regard it as another of many minute steps in the right way. This week there are several such.
Mr. Wells's new " biological fantasia" is perhaps the most comprehensive, if only because of the author's gift for making a cold but irrefutable summary of the contemporary situation. On the customary thread of the fable is strung the future of the world, a choice between folly and hysteria running us further and further into worldwide calamity, and a gradual movement of mankind towards sanity. Like Mr. Joseph Davis, whose career has been the romantic celebration in print of big figures and bigger-seeming causes in the past, we may at first be resentful at the notion that the shooting of cosmic rays across the universe from Mars may threaten humanity, that our children may grow up with a scepticism not inherited from us, and that the whole of life as we know it may cease. But the fantasy is critical, and the criticism persuasive. Failing benevolent interference from another planet we can at least welcome the optimism of this parable, the belief that here and there increasing numbers of men will grow up more sensible and more determined, which is the same to us as "star begotten."
TWO PRACTICAL INSTANCES
As an instance of things whose alteration depends less upon laws than upon a change of heart in those concerned with them we may take Miss Delafield's story of two children whose parents have been divorced and married again. In " Nothing is Safe " the boy is Terry, aged 12, and the girl Julia, two years younger, whose funny inconspicuous care is always saving her highly strung brother from the anger of preoccupied and not very sympathetic parents. Miss Delafield is too conscientious an author, even when she is most amusing, to weight the scales in order to make a story; and so, as the children spend their holidays between father and mother and their grandparents, certain of heart-break houses but no longer clear what they can look on as home, we also get a perfectly fair judgment of modern people. They appear neither as villains nor as heroes, not shamefully neglectful nor fondly self-sacrificing, but as two average modern couples who believe wholeheartedly that the one life they have must be lived and in the process overlook the children. It is a situation that must arise again and again nowadays, and Miss Delafield has carefully understated a case which, shown so simply through the eyes of a child, is more than ever pathetic.
The simplicity of Miss Delafield's method is carried considerably farther in Mr. George Buchanan's " Rose Forbes," which is a full story of endeavour, disappointment, and aspiration written in a compressed style that is extraordinarily effective. Those acquainted only with the fashionable long and prolix novel of to-day will be amazed at the amount of incident and reflection contained in one half the average length. For Rose Forbes, who sustained that first weak husband, a young reporter in Belfast, through courtship and marriage, who went on seeking in life the tenderness without which most of us are only half alive, and who then married, in a kind of reasonable despair, a mayor-to-be in the suburbs of London, life was not uneventful or dull. The struggle for knowledge of herself and of other people was her perpetual interest, and all the events of her career, the work she did and the men and women she met, are invested here with a quick, illuminating sensibility that does not err. But it is the style that is of particular interest, for in these rapid staccato, but suggestive and poetic sentences one seems to find the modern method which many novelists hope to reach in mere colloquialism.
NORWAY IN 1810
One quality, however, most European novelists might take from the Scandinavians, who rarely lose touch with the old realities of human intercourse, with personal decency and fortitude and an upright, not unhumorous morality. It is this lack of cynicism that most attracts the reader to Mr. Gulbranssen's book, a story of life in a great Norwegian yeoman household at the beginning of the last century. Yet "The Wind from the Mountain" does not depend entirely on its simplicities. The routine of farming and hunting and keeping house-how romantic it seems to us to-day, when housekeeping means access to a telephone and a tin-opener !-is broken by all the accidents to which those who live in wild and thinly populated country are subject. When Adelaide Barre marries Young Dag and has to adapt herself to the new life, she enters a community that is largely selfsufficient, that supports itself thriftily on great lands, that finds its adventures in the woods and on the icy mountain, that has its drama in the slow round of birth and growth and ageing. Unlike the stock personages of fiction, the characters are round, continuous but variable.
The excitements of Mr. Townend's story are different, but there is the same reference to character. Sailors, one knows, are shocked by the landsman's fondness for a shipwreck, but from a safe armchair this shipwreck on the reef of an island in the Pacific is irresistible. The survivors struggle ashore to find
themselves marooned within a sharkinfested lagoon enclosed within an almost impassable reef. The adventures of the rescuers and the rescued are exciting enough in themselves, and to these the author has added a variety of anecdotal biographies that give substance to the names of 30 or 40 seamen.
J. S.

NEW NOVELS
RETURN TO THE QUIET
FLOWING DON
VIRGIN SOIL UPTURNED. By MIKHAIL
SHOLOKHOv. Translated from the
Russian by STEPHEN GARRY. (Putnam. 7s. 6d.)
The author of "And Quiet Flows the Don" has skipped the period of reconstrmction after the civil war and chosen to resume his study of the Cossack communities of the Don country at the first phase of the collectivization of agriculture. These Cossack farmers are a primitive, childish, violent, and obstinate people, moved more easily by traditional ideas of their own interest than by argument or cajolery' The author undoubteoly sees them as inidividual human beings rather than as collective exponents of the class struggle in the village. But he has imposed UiDon himself the fatal handicap of a plot of blameless and tediously pedantic orthodoxy. The Communist. worker Davydov, one of the 25,000 Party membe.-s charged with the task of organizing collectivization in-all the principal rural areas, is credible enough-all the more credible, indeed, in that he is a person of averagc abilities and ordinarily healthy instincts. Simultaneously with his arrival in the village of Gremyachy, however, there arrives a far more sinister figure, ai former captain in the Imperial Army, the murderous, treacherous, conspiratorial Polovtsev. It is primarily to the persuasions and machinations of this "wrecker" that Sholokhov ascribes the resistance of the Gremyachy Cossacks to the process of collectivization. This novel has many fine qualities, and contains scenes of not a little dramatic' power, but it leaves an impression of sonmething less than the truth.
MADAME FEARS THE DARK: Seven Stories
and a Play. By MARGARET IRWIN. (Chatto and Windus. 7s. 6d.)
Black magic appears in most of the short stories and in the play which Miss Nvlargaret Irwin has collected in this volume. She has certainly employed all her arts to invest it with reality, and with considerable success; but one begins to weary of witches and black masses before the end. In one tale, "The Earlier Service," Miss Irwin succeeds particularly well in creating an atmosphere of horror. The scene is an old country church haunted by the shadowy presence of an infamous fourteenth-century rector-he becomes fifteenth-century later on, but that is not so probable-who had been tried for celebrating the black mass and decoying children to slay them at the altar. The present rector's daughter was acutely conscious of this presence and driven half demented bv it. Another story with a modern setting, of a man who found on his own bookshelves a manuscript book of Satanic inspiration and fell completely under its spell, is equally grim, though scarcely so powerful. Madame Fears tile Dar-k is a little play showing Mme. de Montespan dying and battling with the evil memories of her youthful dabbling in sorcery. " Mr. Cork " has no magic in it, but is a piece of blistering irony and quite as horrible in its theme as any of the others. Those who enjoy having their flesh made to creep by bugbears of one SOTt or another will find this an excellent specimen of that class of literature.

NEW NOVELS
A STUDY OF ADOLESCENCE
THE EAST WIND OF LOVE. By CObMl'TON
MACKENZIE. Rich and Cowan. Us. 6d. Such is the strength of popular ridicule that it requires courage to take calf-love seriously. Yet popular attitudes are often as shallow as popular people. Leave conventional judgment for a moment and reflect, shyly if need be, upon your own experience; you will admit that first love has a pathetic, transparent honesty that should outweigh whatever charges of silliness and sentimentality subsequent experience may bring against it. It has also this, which may be considered of importance: where later emotions may influence happiness and perhaps events, those first ephemeral passions touch character at its most malleable.
It is with this formative period in a man's life that Mr. Mackenzie deals in the first part of the book to be called "The Four Winds of Love," and he does youth th( justice to suppose that minds as weil as emotions are being evolved. But in an intelligent boy like John Ogilvie leaving school at the turn of the century, it would have been surprising if the mind were not even more disturbed than the body. The death of the Queen seemed to promise an end of the Victorianism against which at any time, and at that time particularly, intelligent youth must rebel. Not that Ogilvie was yet actively and deliberately in revolt, but there was such an influx of ideas that must be examined before he could accept either the established or the potential.
Since he is seventeen when the book opens, these ideas are inextricably caught up with his ideas about women. But life blows cold upon youth in love; and when that wildly unpractical lyric love for Rose Medlicott is forbidden he recovers the sooner for knoWing that he could never have settled down to marriage among the squirearchy. It is typical both of his age and of the time, that his intimacy with Miriam Stern, who was cultured, widelv experienced, and old enough to be his mother, should give him more real satisfaction. Here, by conventional standards, Mr. Mackenzie treads dangerous ground, but he is writing so seriously that conventional standards appear as trivial as any of the brief, almost anecdotal. ep.sodes from which he accumulates so effectively a comprehensive though preliminary account of a contemporary.
THE IRISH FAMINE
FAMINE. By LIAM O'FLAHERTY. Gollancz.
8s. 6d.
After six or seven hours with the reality of Mr. O'Flaherty's Ireland one emerges into the comparative, but nevertheless still comforting, daylight of the present with bewilderment and a guilty feeling of relief. The people of the book are peasants onc never knew, and the year is 1845; even if the people were real they are now far beyond one's power to help; and still this feeling of oppression continues. The blight still hangs, like a solitary and supernatural cloud, over the promising harvest of the valley; the " peelers " are searching the glens for Mary Kilmartin's husband who is wanted for a murder of despair; in their anxiety to relieve the consequences of famine and pestilence the priests are divided among themselves, and the people trudge hopelessly to and from the village for the food that might save them. It is a terrifying effcct, which outruns the means employed to achieve it, and the heartbreaking muddle of incompetence, greed, folly, and misguided heroism is lifted high above the conN'entional limitations of an historical novel. Nor is it only harrowing. The fatalism of the peasant in the face of calamity is thrown aside energetically at thc merest glimmer of hope, and the indomitable will to survive carries Mary and her child cven to an unknown America rather than subside with the rest of the valley into miserv and death.
JAMES VI AND I
MINE IS THE KINGCDOM. By JANE OLIVER.
Collins. Ss. 6d.
A study of the least attractive but not the least interesting of the Stewart Kings, James VI and I, from the pre-natal s'.ock ol Rizzio's murder through the turnwiiis anid cumberis of his minority; his struggles with Spain, England, the Pope of Rome, and that nearcr Pope of Scotland, Andrew Melville; the odd ove.s as adventure of his wooing,; the mattei of the Bonny Earl of Moray and the darker tale of the Gowrie Conspiracy; a glimpsc of the mad epilogue to the Three Hundred Years War; and so to Carey's ride through the March weather to announce the succession to a second CrowU. Miss Oliver has based her slozy on a thorough and genuine study of the time, but the scholarship checks and guides, not overweights it. A reader ignorant of the period will find an exciting tale of complex character and fantastic event, and one who knows enough to realize how closely the author has kept to actual fact will enioy still more her analysis of possible (and very probable) motive, the plausible imaginative filling that she contrives for the gaps in what is known. and the series c-f very convincing portraits. In spite of certain slightly jarring modernisms of language, no one interested in the-Scofland of Queen Mary, or in strange psychology and violent action, is likely to read without keen interest.

" What is fantasy ? " To this might be altered the most famous question in history; war and politics have sanctioned the change. Each incredible alliance, each further invasion is harder t6 believe in, and since truth seems determined to fly in the face of what is likely, let us at least enjoy the holiday she gives us. It is an appropriate time to return to written fantasy, which at any rate harms no one. Disbelief is suspended here as well: we must make the most of Munchausen and his fellows. But there is another and more subtle department of fantasy, one in which the preposterous, like a good caricature, reveals some features of the actual. The latest addition to this is a curious and fascinating comedy by Mr. Peter de Polnay.
It may be said at once that CHILDREN, MY CHILDREN gives as controversial a picture of the child mind as " A High Wind in Jamaica" did. Life here is on two planes. There is the superficial fantasy of the beastly, black-browed Mr. Nicholas, whose wife shoots herself because she is refused a divorce; and there is.the funny, attractive, and, it seems, perfectly serious record of his children's thoughts. The loss of his wife is the least of Mr. Nicholas's concerns, once he has persuaded himself that she never meant to leave him. He is a villain in the best tradition, boastful, opinionated, selfish, and wanton; he is always ready to make love to a governess, or believe himself wronged by a mistress who grows wearisome; and, since it is 1914, he wears a moustache. For all his vagaries the children must provide their own explanations, and Mr. de Polnay gives the most lively and persuasive account of the way in which small children rationalize the absurd behaviour of the grown-up world. He knows that at the age of eight or nine one is ignorant of the stupid motives of one's elders, and that one credits them instead with motives that seem reasonable to oneself. Munmny, who has Ivor and Molly and Edith to' love, can have no reason for shooting herself: therefore Father, whom they all fear and dislike, must have shot her; and the idea persists. The three children are quite distinct, and as the absorbing story proceeds they seem to grow. It is a remarkably good mixture of the ridiculous and the hardheaded.
NINE NOVELS
Of the nine stories and novels in Mr. Louis Bromfield's collection, two have appeared before, those entitled "Better than Life" and " McLeod's Folly." The rest have various scenes and subjects but are united in dealing, one may fancy, less with the real world than with a story-book one. Thus a prince's mistress, devoted to him but long in exile, finds him again in New York, where the lovers perish in an hotel fire. Or an actress in New York in the nineties is such a very good sort that she makes love to a poor little English valet just to make up to him for an unhappy upbringing. Or a well-to-do neurotic gentleman, who has tried in vain to forget a lady he might very well have married, finds sanctuary at last in an exotic and decaying seaside village and has just married a half-caste when the lady from his past reappears with a rich, elderly, and unpleasant husband. In situations such as these it will not be the author's fault if nothing happens, and, indeed, the chief merit of the stories is their eventfulness. Mr. Bromfield is never at a loss for an anecdote or a scene in passing or a bit of local colour, and in " New York Legend," the one about the prince's mnistress, quite the most interesting parts of the story are connected with persons not essential to it. His people, however, have one fault-they are seldom rebellious. They do as they are told, and in rather an interesting way; but it is only in one or two of them-Mees Opp, for instance, in " Bitter Lotus "-that the character seems alive and only waiting till the author's back is turned.
AN EAST END DRAPER
There is rather more humanity in THEY NVON'T LET You LIVE, though Mr. Simon Blumenfeld is not so accomplished a storyteller. He, too, uses slightly fantastic means, though he is seriously concerned for his people. They are the Curries, shopkeepers in the East End for three or four generations. In 1939, however, small drapers have to face great competition, and Currie's is on the road to ruin. Mr. Blumenfeld shows the present shopkeeper trying to reconcile his faith in honesty and plain dealing with what his son recognizes as an inevitable development in commerce. Currie fails and, after such desperate stratagems as backing horses, he shoots himself. It is all rather sad, but beneath the earnestness one perceives the author's sincere concern for the unfortunate, and for this one is disposed to be sympathetic. At least he regards writing as something more than a means to gain a living. But there are passages in which he forgets the injustice of life and sees about him a life that does not run in conventional channels, a life in which even the victims fail to dwell on their misfortunes; and in these he promises more.
The last is a frail and pleasant piece. Miss LAVINGTON is a story for those who prefer not to be racked, or even upset, by their reading. A woman returns after 50 years to the scene of her childhood and youth, and the first thing she does is to cry "Edward ! " and faint. This is because she opens a door and sees, dressed ready to play a part in Milestones, the living image of the man she might have married. After the first faint Miss Lavington controls herself, and on the whole she is pleased, though her memories are vivid enough for her to be also a little jealous, when her niece falls in love with the present Edward Wheatley. It is an ambling, amiable book, made up of new events in old associations, and it depends on the theory that the old believe themselves to be very old. Miss Lavington is only in her sixties, but any one would believe she had played with Miss Yonge:
J. S.

TWO NEW NOVELS.
“ A GOLFING PRODIGY.”
Mr. Mark Allerton is a pleasant writer, with a preference for dealing with the philosophy of life in general under the name of golf rather than with the more technical aspects of the game.
In the earlier part of his book he has acted up to this sound principle so very thoroughly that the golfing reader begins to accuse him of false pretences. Here is a book bound in green, called The Girl on the Green (Methuen, 6s.), and adorned with "a representation of a bag of clubs, and no word of golf till the neighbourhood of page 80 is reached. Instead there is a mildly engaging young lady, Miss Frances Eveleigh, froin the College of Barton, who has been sufficiently interested in the suffrage movement to break a window*- and a cheerful, slangy - young gentleman;-"the Hon. -’James Beverly, against whom there is "nothing whatever to be said, except that we are not surprised to hear that his father is the first rather than the
tenth baron. Then putting greens begin to be made, suffragists attempt, under cover of darkness, to destroy them, and the heroine, by means of some rather ingenious plotting, is suspected of the outrage, Meanwhile she has been learning golf under the eye of Mr. Beverly—who, it appears, has reached the semi-final of the amateur championship—and falling in love with him at the same time, although refusing him most stoutly, as she does in different chapters a number of other and far less attractive gentlemen.
It is only when these two are engaged, and the love interest conscientiously disposed of, that the reader gets his full money’s worth of golf. Suddenly a great match is arranged between Mr. Beverly and Miss Eveleigh in which the gentleman is to concede the odds of a half. It is played before crowds of spectators, amid terrific excitement, and, after a dramatic finish, is won by the hero by a single hole. The description of the match, or some part of it, is conceived in a frankly farcical vein. It is therefore perhaps pedantic to boggle at possibilities; but really the male golfing sense of what is credible does overcome our sense of humour and compel us to utter a matter-offact protest, with which the author, being a Scotsman, may covertly sympathize. A few years ago a match was played at Stoke Poges between teams of male and female players of considerable repute, and the men giving a half won comfortably. Yet here a young lady who only a.few months from her first holding a golf club can not only win a county championship with a score of 75, but at the aforesaid odds of a half take to the very last hole on. a long seaside course the favourite for the male amateur championship.
This is surely the most remarkable achievement of its kind since a gentleman in “ The Lady of the Lake ” cleared eighteen feet with a standing long jump. It is very entertaining, but it really won’t do,
“A GIRL’S MARRIAGE.”
Sensibility of a- rather disturbing kind tempers the easy flow of events in A Girl’s Marriage, by Agnes Gordon Lennox (Lane, 6s.), and emotions which some people might think very undesirable are curiously combined with a dilemma in morals. As for the story, men and women of charm are grouped together in an opulent circle. The atmosphere is refined without being rarefied. Nobody has any special object- in life beyond being decently turned out and properly valeted, and all seems very neatly devised to secure ■ a delightful world. But- still there is room for a serious theme and a delicate problem.
Marriage is the question. .Ignorance of physical marriage is the crux. Fay Beaumont, devoted to her brothers, in love with family life, chooses to plunge into marriage with Lord Malcolm Kinross not knowing what she is doing. Such is her lack of knowledge that she recoils in horror from contact with reality. Daisy Pierpoint-, her friend, on the other hand, learns the pleasure-pains of life’s chief secret
less regularly, with less resentment at the time, and with rebellion, apparently, only as an after-thought" which coincidence, brings about for the_sake of. the story. With Fay Beaumont in the foreground, the, reader will wateb. the stirrings of. nature with many a thrill, though perhaps they will wonder why the lady doth protest so much. This, not because the thing itself is impossible by any means, but because Fay is Fay, "a person true enough to type in herself not.to .antagonize the immutable laws' of nature pr to require the sacrifice of the unfortunate Malcolm and his quick effacement. Mr. Mark Allerton is a pleasant writer, with a preference for dealing with the philosophy of life in general under the name of golf rather than with the more technical aspects of the game. In the earlier part of his book he has acted up to this sound principle so very vigorously that the golfing reader begins to accuse him of false pretenses. Here is a book bound in green, called The Girl on the Green Menhaden, 6s., adorned with a representation of a bag of clubs, and no word of golf until the vicinity of page 80 is reached. Instead there is a mildly engaging young lady, Miss Frances Ewell, from the College of Barton, who has been sufficiently interested in the suffrage movement to break a window- and a cheerful, slangy- young gentleman-the Hon.-James Beverly, against whom there is nothing whatever to be said, except that we are not surprised to hear that his father is the first rather than the tenth baron. Then putting greens begin to be made, and suffragists attempt, under cover of darkness, to destroy them, and the heroine, by means of some rather ingenious plotting, is suspected of the outrage, Meanwhile she has been learning golf under the eye of Mr. Beverly, who, it appears, has reached the semi-final of the amateur championship and is falling in love with him at the same time, although resisting him most strongly, as she does in different chapters a number of other more attractive gentlemen. It is only when these two are engaged, and the love affair is conscientiously dissected, that the reader gets his full money's worth of golf. Suddenly a great match is arranged between Mr. and Miss Ewell, in which the gentleman is to concede. concede the odds of a half. It is played before crowds of spectators, in tremendous excitement, and, after a dramatic finish, is won by the hero by a single shot. The description of the match, or some part of it, is conceived in a rather farcical vein. It is perhaps dangerous to boggle at the possibilities of golfing success, but the real sense of what is credible does overcome our sense of humour and compels us to utter a matter-of-fact protest, with which the author, being a Scotsman, may covertly sympathise. A few years ago a match was played at Stoke Park between teams of men and female players of considerable repute, and the men gave a half-way win. Yet here a young lady who only has a few months to hold a golf club can not only win a county championship with a score of 75, but at the same time take the chance to take the very last hole on a long seaside course the favorite for the female amateur championship. This is surely the most remarkable achievement of its kind since a gentleman in the Lady of the Lake cleared eighteen feet with a standing long jump. It is very entertaining, but it really won't do, A GIRL'S MARRIAGE. Sensibility of a rather disturbing kind tempers the easy flow of events in A Girl's Marriage, by Agamemnon Lennox, 6s., and emotions which some people might think are very desirable are curiously combined with a dilemma in morals. morals. As for the story, men and women of charm are grouped together in an opulent circle. The atmosphere is unrefined and unfiltered. Nobody has any special object--in life beyond being decently turned out and properly vested, and all that seems to be designed to secure a delightful world. But there is still room for a serious theme and a delicate problem. Marriage is the question. Ignorance of physical marriage is the crux. Fancy Beaumont, devoted to her brothers, in love with her family life, chooses to marry Sir Malcolm Kinross without knowing what she is doing. Such is her lack of knowledge that she refracts in horror from contact with reality. Daisy Pierpoint--her friend, on the other hand, learns the pleasure-pains of life's chief secret less frequently, with less resentment at the time, and with a rebellion, perhaps only as an afterthought, which brings about a delay in the story. With Fanny and Bess, in the foreground, the reader will be aware of the stirrings of nature. with much pleasure, though perhaps they will wonder why the Lady did so much. This is not because the thing itself is impossible by any means, but because Fanny is a person who is true enough to type in herself not to attempt to antagonize the immutable laws of nature to require the sacrifice of the unfortunate Malcolm and his immediate effacement. That struck us as somewhat artificial, all the more because it is a prelude to Fanny's awakening after a suitable delay at the time. at the bidding of the dead man. Yet it catches our attention, and its restraint in this 7-year-old novel is quite convincing, given the other characters who circle around the author. The poor woman who is making this novel is just about as pretty as she can be.
