There is a certain outlandishness, admirable when it is merely of plot and setting, injudicious perhaps where it touches character, to be found in each of the five novels reviewed below. Each is off the well-worn track, but whether for good or ill depends upon the destination for which the individual author is making. Mrs. Buck, at any rate, is in no doubt about hers. The Heaven of the Old Testament is the only conceivable end for so rampageous an angel as Andrew Stone, for whom the mission-field in China is as a battlefield in God's war and the enemy to be routed alternately the devil of ignorance or human opposition. Born of a narrow, pugnacious, egotistical Southern family, he was bound to bully and fight in whatever calling he chose, and when it chanced to be that of evangelist he left America and applied that vast energy and indomitable obstinacy to the subjugation of the foreign heathen. That was years before the Boxer Rising, when China was comparatively new country for this rather equivocal kind of crusade; and for 50 years Andrew sacrificed himself and his family to the propagation of the Gospel.
It was easy for him. He had a single purpose and wvas consumed by a flame that sustained him even while it gave him no rest. The suspicious regularity with which God's will matched his own was a coincidence he never noticed. Had it not been for his wife, whose story was related in an earlier book, his own family might have been in a far worse case than the Chinese he loved. In spite of the vigorous irony, which the author handles with so much care and so greatly to our satisfaction, the flame burns with assurance, flickering a little before the prospect of meeting Jehovah face to face, but disturbed by no earthly wind and illumining, as Mrs. Buck intended, the portrait of a soul that admitted no human responsibility.
A SCIENTIFIC "THRILLER"
Mr. Macpherson's ingenious and extremely stimulating scientific " thriller " comes out with the emphasis on a point directly opposite. Plant three modern people upon an island in the St. Lawrence -a brilliant young English scientist, say, his lively and intelligent wife, and a friendly Canadian journalist who has sensibly put aside his former passion for the lady-subject them to a series of what look like magical attacks, and a man will still, in spite of science, culture and a healthy cynicism, act like an animal in an emergency and fight for the woman to whom he is married. And they are very curious attacks, this owl that defies the canon of its kind and flies at their eyes, these phantoms of a knight in armour and a merciless lady, the butler and handyman who dances under hypnotism, these voices in mid air that bawl at the lady and the journalist horrible distortions of their own thoughts. So well contrived is the atmosphere of uncertainty and dread that can becloud the minds of even reasonable people in extraordinary circumstances that the explanation, however ingenious scientifically, comes as an anticlimax, and it requires all the rest of the adventure, the voyage through the Thousand and One Islands and the frightful, visible reconstruction of a single indiscretion to restore our interest in a most original fantasy for the enjoyment of reasonable people.
It is another kind of terror that stalks through the two stories in " Murder for Love." In one a young girl whose life is made wretched by a bestial and drunken grandmother gives her an overdose of sleeping draught: in the other a frustrated wife whose chastity, like her husband's, is bound up with all sorts of prohibitions. knifes the man. But the terror lies not in these, by the standards of fiction rather commonplace incidents, but in the madness that follows or begets them. Both set up in the reader the same inquiry: Can one safely deduce the emotions of lunacy from the emotions of a normal woman ? Miss Salt has followed the same course in both cases by trying to enter the mind of the lunatic and inviting us to share her dread of the twilit world in which she wanders. We concede the horror in theory but actually are little moved. When there is so much to engross a novelist and his readers in the world that directly touches us a flight into a region where all is dark. melancholy and. at best, extremely problematical must be made magnificently before it can command attention.
ARDEN BEFORE ROSALIND
Even without this contrast " One Man's Holiday" is deliciously normal, so normal, indeed, that it sinks at times to the ordinary. Only the frailest skeleton of plot-a young Englishman on holiday in Greece, a Greek girl and a matchmaking friend-distinguishes the tale from an informal, tentative and sometimes very amusing travel book. The young man-whose name, by the way, is Parker-travels to Greece, of which, very engagingly, he knows nothing, by cargo steamer; he motors over bad roads, he learns to open a conversation with a remark on politics instead of on the weather, he has miniature adventures of the type the usual tourist experiences, and he throws off at length the shyness of a conventional young man whose life till now has been passed between an accountants office and a bachelor flat. It gives an agreeable view of modern Greek life and an amiable picture of the people, and it is politely and humorously written; but Mr. Dickson has still to write a novel.
Though Mr. Phillpotts's latest romance is officially set in England, in the " Blore " country, it might very well be in the Limberlost or some other large and romantic wood. Though the song of the cardinal is not to be heard, a little girl makes friends with the trees in the best Limberlost manner, and life in general, even to the shuffling off of an unwise marriage, has a felicitous simplicity absent from life in
ordinary society. There is an old wisc woman and her beautiful, colcd son, who adopt the little girl whose father has married again and, to her mind as well as his, uncomfortably. The child is fond of sermons, particularly those found in trees; and with its handful of rustics and the kindly, rather academic clergyman, the whole thing has something of the peaceful monotony of life in Arden before the arrival of Rosalind.

Author: Wagner, Erica
Title: Recipe for Classics? A Pinch of Genius Needed
Full_text:
RECIPE FOR CLASSICS? A PINCH OF GENIUS NEEDED
EVER GAZED at the handsome black spine of a Penguin Classic and thought, "Now , how could I write one of those?" Well, if you have, you're in luck — Nigel Wilcockson, publisher of Penguin Classics, has the formula. "I once tried to come up with a sort of recipe for how to write a classic novel — ie, a novel that would still be read in 100 years' time. So, to start with, it's very dangerous to write only one book — though Alain Fournier got away with it But don't write too many, either, because people stop taking you seriously: look at Edgar Wallace. It doesn't get you very far being an innovator; 100 years later, people might think, what's so innovative about that? And," — a warning for those follow - ing a current literary vogue — "don't write his - torical novels. The more I look at it, the more I think they date. In the same way, if you look at costume drama from the 1970s, it looks like the 1970s. People don't read old historical novels be - cause it's not true about the period if s meant to be addressing, and it's not quite talking about the period if s written in, either. Genre novels are a good idea: so I think that Agatha Christie will still be read in 50 years, but Catherine Cook - son will be out of print" He laughs. "Thafs my rather dangerous prediction!" But then, with a more serious look, he admits that this is a recipe not everyone can follow. "There is one problem — the last thing is, you have to be a genius. " Wilcockson, 41, is talking to me in his com -
" AGATHA CHRISTIE WILL BE READ IN 50 YEARS' TIME, BUT CATHERINE COOKSON MAY WELL BE OUT OF PRINT" fortable office in Penguin's fine new home on the Strand — if you crane your neck in looking out his window, you can see the river, Westmin - ster , the Millennium Wheel. I've come because the relaunch of Penguin Classics — the first re - launch in 16 years, only the fourth in the series' history — has made me wonder if "classic texts" aren't something we're in danger of taking just a little too much for granted. Penguin Classics were initally lauched in a spirit of postwar en - thusiasm — the classicist and publisher E. V.
Rieu had spent his idle hours during service in the Second World War perfecting his transla - tion of Homer's Odyssey ("its revision was un - dertaken to the sound of VI and V2 explosions and the crash of shattering glass," he wrote); he read it aloud to his wife Nelly, who encouraged him to try to get it published. Allen Lane not only took the leap, but also invited Rieu to edit a series of classics; a decision that was surely an act of faith, but one that was soon vindicated:
PENGUIN'S TOP TEN CLASSIC SELLERS Jane Austen: Emma lane Austen: Pride and Prejudice Emily Bronte: Wuthering Heights Charlotte Bronte: Jane Eyre Geoffrey Chaucer: The Canterbury Tales Charles Dickens: Great Expectations Homer The Odyssey Nlccolo Machlavelli: The Prince Plato: The Republic Mary Shelley: Frankenstein
since 1946 Rieu's Odyssey has sold nearly three million copies — the bestselling Penguin until it was eclipsed by Lady Chatterley's Lover 15 years later. But surely things are different now, and Wil - cockson 's position is very different from Lane's. The "classic books" — we all know what they are, don't we? Wikockson's job must be a pretty cushy one, don't you think? Just a matter of slap - ping on some swish new covers and Bob's your uncle? Penguin's commitment to both scholars and general readers is what has distinguished its books. What comes across most in talking to Wilcockson is what he must share with Lane and Rieu: a real commitment to the books un - der his care, a willingness to make a tremen - dous effort to—if s not too.excessive a compari - son — spread the gospel. He has, for instance, developed a passion for George Gissing, which he admits at the moment that almost no one shares: "but all that's going to change next year" when Gissing comes under the umbrella of the relaunch. Of course, you can't make people buy books, and there's no guarantee of success: Ms concern is genuine when he notes a change in fashion. The Canterbury Tales remains a strong seller, he tells me, but Troilus and Criseyde sells a fifth as many copies as it did 30 years ago. He fears for the fate of medieval literature. "Occasionally you get people invoking this terrible word 'relevance' when talking about lit - erature ; and it just makes me want to go and stick my head in the oven. I've heard it a lot late - ly about medieval literature and if s a pernicious thing. No one will stop reading The Canterbury Tales , but it gets harder and harder to enthuse people about the area around it. It's as though everyone should be writing manuals for how to drive a Ford Mondeo, because that's 'relevant." We both note in despair that it's even a misuse of the word: relevant to what?

Yet if you insist upon "relevance", you need only turn to the back of the relaunched edition of Herodotus. Wilcockson has been insistent where blurbs for the new books are concerned: Penguin's mission is to arouse, not assume, in - terest , to try to give the reader a sense of the book and not just convey that it's something that should be read "because if s good for you". To that end, a quote from the book is always in - cluded on the coven "No one is fool enough to choose war instead of peace — in peace sons bury fathers, but in war fathers bury sons", the ancient historian remarked. What could be more relevant to our present situation than that? Of course, no list is complete, and Wilcock - son is forthright about the gaps in the Penguin list; he notes a dearth of Far Eastern and tradi - tional Jewish texts — even things closer to home, like German Romantic literature: there's Goethe, but not much Schiller. Rectifying such gaps can be slow, and an academic impetus can be needed to help to get things off the ground. And the process of "becoming a classic", pace Wilcockson's formula, is a slow and mysterious one.
"What is a classic? We use three criteria, real - ly : one is this terribly difficult thing, of some - thing being 'a great book' — thaf s part deter - mined by survival", it's self-selecting . Then you have the books that are just wonderful reads: that Orwell described as 'good bad books', like those of Wilkie Collins. He's not Tolstoy, but he's wonderful to read Then there are books that tell you something about the time that they were written. That goes right back to the begin - ning of the idea of the classics, with Greek and Latin. I don't think Xenophon is a great, great writer, but you read him because you find out about the Persian expedition, say. And I think thaf s something that's increasingly important, especially as we have got very nervous about talking about 'a canon'. But the great books thing is the mystery. No one knows what makes a great book. It would be sad if we did." Wilcockson's delight — and the delight of his readers — is that we all must keep looking for them, even when we think they are under our noses. Books that speak across ages and cul - tures , from Gilgamesh to Middlemarch: "classic", where a literature is concerned, means not lost in its time, but something perpetually new.

Author: Oltermann, Philip
Title: The new way forward is back
Full_text:
T? ndpapers
The new way forward is back
Palm Pilot Man claimed that the electronic world would kill off books. Not so, Philip Oltermann says. It has simply made us more aware of their beauty
Big is beautiful: TheAtlas Maior of mm
A FEW DAYS AFTER THE London Review Bookshop opened in Bloomsbury two-and-a-half years ago, a salesperson manoeuvred past the lavish display of new hardbacks, stepped up to the counter ofthe manager, Andrew Stilwell, and placed a smooth metal object in front of him. This, he said proudly, was the future of books. Others in the queue held their breath. A Palm Pilot. Thank you, but no it wasn't, Stilwell said. They sold Gameboys down the road. The Palm Pilot Men talk with much confidence about publishing these days. The era of the printed page, they claim, is ending. The future is digital, paperless and Bluetooth-compatible. Bill Gates insists that Microsoft's portable Tablet PC — launched in 2002 — could render traditional publishing obsolete in four to five years. But take any of the apostles of the e-book to a bookshop this Christmas and they might lose some of their swagger. They may pick up the new McSweeney's Quarterly, for example. The American author Dave Eggers's playful, experimental journal for fiction, now on its sixteenth issue, has perfected the old-fashioned, dusty tome look: these are books that look like books. The latest is a cheeky foldout number, complete with a pack of playing cards and comb. They may also chance upon
Taschen's table-sized Atlas Maior of 1665, a reprint of Joan Blaeu's baroque masterpiece of mapmaking. The original's 596 maps came in 11 volumes, and kept Blaeu's copperplate presses busy for 1,600 days. Perhaps it is just coincidence that Taschen decided to republish it in the year that Google launched its virtual globe project, Google Earth. At £100 a copy, it doesn't come cheap, but then the price has symbolic value: quality doesn't sell for £99.99. The result of an even more painstaking labour of love is Audrey Niffenegger's The Three Incestuous Sisters. Her bestselling novel The Time Traveler's Wife took five years to travel from the conception of its title to the bookshelves in Sainsbury's — no time at all, compared with her visual tale of jealous siblings, ghostly ancestors and flying babies. Using aquatint, she spent 14 years making ten copies. Before Cape decided to publish a cheaper mass market version, they sold for around £1,000 each. Collector's edition chic is also in vogue: Zadie Smith's On Beauty, for example, comes complete with beautifully patterned endpapers — a design quirk that one used to find almost exclusively in special editions. Even the booklets in Penguin's "Great Ideas" series, with their proud typography and ornamental frames, look like the sort of thing that one would pick
up at a fine press fair not a book chain. Waterstone's picked up on the success of internet book auction sites earlier this year and started commissioning special editions from publishers. Commercially successful new titles — from Kazuo Ishiguro to Lauren Bacall — now come with a slightly more expensive collectable twin. Far from pushing traditional bookmaking to the edge, internet publishing seems to have breathed new life into it and reminded it of its strengths. Any of the above titles could make your iBook melt with envy, so self-assured are they in their celebration of the nostalgic, emotive qualities ofthe book as a material object. Simon Prosser, the Penguin editor who decided to publish McSweeney's in Britain, says: "You can pick them up, put them down, take them to bed, admire the way they've been conserved within their covers, show them off to your friends or smell the distinctive scent of print on paper. Centuries of piety have made the Bible inaccessible to many modern readers , and The Literary Guide to the Bible is an attempt to demythologize the Good Book and to approach it as any other text. Using the techniques of modern literary criticism, scholars have contributed essays on each of the major books of the Bible. Many of these are excellent; they restore authenticity to texts which have become over-familiar or devalued by narrow fundamentalism. Thus James Ackerman shows that the Book of Jonah is a poignant but witty satire, of facile religiosity. Robert Alter examines the language of the psalms to show how skilfully they depict a world made nu - minous and immediate by faith. Pharisaic and rab - binic Judaism did not analyse scripture to discern the authors' intentions, but believed interpre - tation and commentary were as au - thoritative as the texts themselves. Early Jewish Christians rewrote

In his essay on the Epistle to the Hebrews, he shows that the Jewish scriptures had been content to affirm that there was meaning, without defin - ing this too closely, but the New Testament writers insisted they knew exactly what that meaning was. Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS
_-
HANDEL RICHARDSON'S
I STORIES
THE END or A CHILDHOOD AND OTHER
STORIES. By HENRY HANDEL RICHARDSON. (Heinemann. 7s. 6d. net.)
Those who have complained-and most even of her greatest admirers have done it at one time or aAother-that Henry Handel Richardson writes at too great length will take up this book of short stories with interest. "Maurice Guest" was enormously long, and so was the first of the three books about Richard Mahony. "The End of a Childhood" fills fewer than 70 pages, and it proves that this author understands the art of saying much in little. The tale, naturally, will have more in it for those who know what Cuffy Mahony's father was like and something more than what the story tells them about his mother and Henry Ocock, and Tilly. But it is a complete story, complete because of its revelation of a boy's mind and heart, and not the less complete because it leaves the boy on the verge of a new sort of life and does not say what happened to him in it. It achieves precisely what it set out to do, and, like all good short stories of its kind, leaves the rest for the reader to do. Nearly everything in the book, indeed, shows Henry Handel Richardson's skill in that very diflicult task of first seeing what the point is and then of clearing it for the reader to see. The eight little glimpses (they -are not stories) called " Growing Pains" seem to peep, with the wisest mixture of reverence, fun, and pity, and then to look quickly away; but in each glimpse we have seen some aspect of girlhood which a duller eye might not have observed for us and a heavier hand might have made us wish we had not seen. Of the other stories, that which best reveals the author's peculiar skill in choosing so much detail as is necessary to her idea, and no more, is " Mary Christina," a study of an old woman's last illness and death and of her thoughts about life as it leaves her. But "Succedaneum" will be welcome to many for recalling "Maurice Guest," and showing how the author's art has ripened and refined in the intervening years.
A HANDFUL OF DUST. By EVELYN
WAUGH. (Chapman and Hall. 7s. 6d. net.)
At a guess we should say that Mr. Evelyn Waugh came by the notion that he has developed in "A Handful of Dust" during a discussion on the disappearance of Colonel Fawcett in Brazil. Having recently, as we know, spent "Ninety-two Days" in those parts, he-however sardonically silent-would be appealed to as an authority when all heroic hypotheses had been exhausted. Thereupon he may have delivered himself of the predicament in which he leaves Tony Last, the chief character in his new novel. To recuperate from marital and other troubles at home, the inept Tony went on a voyage to Georgetown. He allowed himself to be persuaded into accompanying a Waughish explorer. The porters desert, the explorer is drowned, Tony wandering alone is picked up by a Mr. Todd, a Waughish hermit of the bush. Mr. Todd has few possessions except a set of novels of Dickens; he cannot read himself, but he once had a companion who read Dickens aloud to him: So he holds Tony captive to perform for him a like service; and as Tony is quite incapable of travelling alone through the dense bush, he is there for the rest of his days.
The early part of the book is a preparation in the Waughish manner for his finale. In it we have Tony playing the squire on his estate, Hetton Abbey.. The company is the smart set as known to or imagined by Mr. Waugh, and the distinctive feature of his style lies in the smooth detachment with which he chronicles the doings of his iridescent parasites and also their sufferings.
THE CURATE'S WIFE. By E. H. YOUNG.
(Cape. 7s. 6d. net.)
This continuation of the story of Dahlia and Jenny Rendall, begun in " Jenny NVren," will give perfect satisfaction to all Miss Young's readers, old and new. The relations between the sisters have been reversed, and Dahlia is now our chief interest. Her marriage to Cecil Sproat, the curate, is going to be a complete success, but the steps towards success are slow and sometimes painful. Miss Young explains them to us at length with all her accustomed wit and delicate svmpathv. The sublety of the drawing of these two rather touching young people is beyond praise. As a foil to them we have the vicar and his wife. Mrs. Doubleday has made the great mistake all her life of seltisnly idolizing the son who must naturally turn from her some day, and despising the husband who, with all his faults, must be her final refuge. Her natural dislike of youth and charm make her far from kind to Dahlia, whose parrying of her rudeness is delightful comedy. Meanwhile Cecil is hurt by Dahlia's pleasure in Simon Tothill's philandering society and rather jealous of Jenny. How Dahlia by her humour,, her affection, and her young steadfastness regains her Cecil, and how Cecil fights against his less kind thoughts and regains his Dahlia, only Miss Young can tell, without sentiment, yet with strong feeling.
PORTRAIT OF HIS EXCELLENCY. By STEPHEN
McKENNA. (Hutchinson. 7s. 6d. net.)
Mr. McKenna's new novel is a comment on the differences between public report and private experience. He takes the case of Richard Croyle, and by way of presenting the account of him accepted by the world at large, gives as a heading to each of his 12 chapters an excerpt from a fantiliar book of reference: " Alster, 3rd Viscount . . ."; "Educated: Eton and Magdalen . . .", "Married, 1908, Felicity . . ."; and so on through the list of his services and achievements to his appointment as Governor-General of Australia. The official biography, published after
Lord Alster's death, was founded on such material as this, and added nothing of first importance about the man himself. Mr. McKenna, in the person of Leslie Vivian, now proceeds to tell us the inner history of his friend Dick Croyle's life. It is not by any means a scandalous story. If it had been known to the public it would not have made much difference to Lord Alster's career, but no detail of it could have been inferred from any work of reference or from the official biography. * Mr. McKenna examines sincerely and patiently the springs of motive that with the accidents of circumstance determined the record, and so gives to it an entirely new interpretation. "Portrait of His Excellency" is a very honest piece of work, executed with the skill of an cxperienced. craftsman.

But he holds a mirror up to our own death and the unknown beyond the grave, compounding it with an uncomfortably familiar experience of living-and-loving death outside the confines of the body and a lingering insuficiency of human love. and the reality of human loneliness. These mighty themes - the apocalypse of abstract beauty - shrink into oblivion when the death of a loved one occurs. Only old Conrad Hartley, a great deal older than David, seems to understand it a bit. Alone with his books and the dreadful turn of his genealogical research, his loneliness overlaid with the squalor of his beloved wife's death twenty years earlier, Conrad has observed that most of us tend to resemble strangers even to those closest to us, suggesting, gently, that David's only real relationship was with David. Miss Mooney has done a lot of thinking. Men and women isolated in confusion, innocence, or desperation fill the pages of this novel, a relatively undemanding everyday mystery of middleclass life, their everyday perceptions of death and its consequences. A long hand of coincidence casts doubt on all our lives. and the horror of its consequences. more literary style than Ben Mooney's agreeably plain prose, though less readable, though more powerful and moving, for an overly familiar acquaintance with grief. Now in the courtroom of his own mind, the advocate of death is held in high repute. Americans shackled to this sort of thing do not travel in perfect comfort to this country. William Haines is an admirable, successful novelist, but the complex meditations on the death of Belmore by Ben Mooney and the subsequent voyages of Willie Hopper by Aldous Huxley are both powerful and moving. Above the level of a railway guide, The Swimming Pool by Rosalind Russell is readable in its entirety. XXVII. There is an internal struggle between internal and external activity that is greater than all but the most devotedly doomed followers of fiction seem likely to appreciate. Between his 48th and 50th birthdays, Ben Turnbull has lost a son, a long-term friend, a great deal of weight and, it appears, has lost all reasonable hope of emotional equilibrium, even though his wife has gone off to live alone with his grandson. Once again, suicide is at the apex of different kinds of death and mourning. Again, there is no known reason. Ben, who used to like fishing, goes fishing again. Fisherman, read on. One man and his boat, with enough patience, can bring a heavy novel safely. Rosalind's fourth novel is a gloomy read if you are trying to lose weight. It is a catalogue of delicious food and characters tossed about in the little village of Pomegranate, in the Dordogne, and more sophisticated sister in the south of England. Mutually exclusive examples of metaphysics shift back and forth across the Channel like fluttering eyelids and the glinting corpses of dead people in their sleep. I can imagine very good. No? Sadly, not even with a French accent. The summer sunshine seems more synthetic than the colour of Dolores de la Bouche, the woman recalled to a dying mother's rabid fan club in Oxford. A large cast - led by Larry and Miriam Kendall, the one planning his swimming pool against the impotent resistance of Miss de la Bossa, the other recalling a dead mother in her bed - breaks the novel into less than the sum of its parts. Miss Otis regrets it.

Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS
UNROMANTIC SEAMEN
,Mr. William McFee's WATCH BELOWV (Faber and Faber, 9s. 6d.) is a book with character. It denies the romantic legend that life at sea is nothing but storms and misadventure, and it settles down very sensibly to show us seamen, and particularly the engineers, at their ordinary work. The story is essentially only an illustration to a sort of lively monograph, but the monograph has the interest of most documentary writing and is, in fact, absorbing. Here, we may believe, are a true picture of conditions in a British tramp steamer -before the last war and a just study of the minds of those aboazd her. Some of the hardships, necessary or unnecessary, handed down from the days of sail had already been remitted, but there was no break in the tradition of pride in one's work. Engineers grumbled at antiquated and uneconomical machinery but were secretly proud of what they could get out of it, and masters not yet within the reach of wireless instructions enjoyed a very real responsibility. None of them were men who could have been happy ashore, where they would have had more pay and shorter hours, and their romantic notions of life ashore resemble those that many landsmen have of life at sca. Mr. McFee looks at them dispassionately and with humour and finds them good.
In RESPECTABLE PERSONS (Hutchinson, 7s. 6d.) tMr. Arthur Caddick is similarly unromantic about the British ashore. A young man from the Continent comes to England in order to study a nation he has always admired, and he unfortunately elects to stay with a family named Robinson in a small provincial town. Everywhere he finds hypocrisy, sometimes harmless and amusing, sometimes not, and it must be said that Mr. Caddick manages to substantiate this old charge fairly and with good temper. The Robinsons are necessarily conventionalized, but they represent a complacency and an ignorance that are only now beginning to disappear, and Mr. Caddick is merely doing for us what wc have frequently done for other brecds. And he has the grace to return his visitor to an even more irresponsible .home.
ENVOY ON EXCURSIoN, by Caryl Brahms and S. J. Simon (Michael Joseph, 8s.), is sometimes much more trcnchant. It is a lunatic comedy of Whitehall in wartimc, a neutral kingdom with products desired by both Great Britain and Germany, and Adam Quill, the detective who discovered who shot the bullet in the ballet. Stroganoff's Russian ballet comes in again for a gala performance in the Capital of Insomnia, but the present lunacy is concerned more particularly with politics, with drugged coffee and hopelessly inefficient and venial spies, and with the rise of the Nazi party in Insomnia-up-to the age of 15-and Herrvon Papcn's tendency to miss the train. The brew is kept bubbling with mischief, with malice, and with an invention that seldom hesitates.
We may end with a glance at the short stories by Mr. Fred Urquhart collected in I FELL FOR A SAILOR (Duckworth, 7s. 6d.).. Mr. Urquhart has a good range and can handle the satirical, the pathetic, -and the comic with some talent. His best work is, in fact, comic, for in "Being a Bohemian," for instance, he draws his character -and makes his comment impersonally, without the sometimes embarrassing sympathy that is shown in one or two of the pathetic pieces. Even in these there is no complete failure. J. S.

Author: Davis, Clive
Title: Comedy
Full_text:
COMEDY
PerrierPick of the Fringe Her Majesty 's CMve Davis SOME years ago I interviewed Shaun Hutson, the bestselling writer who has made a killing from extravagantly graphic semi-literate horror novels that make Stephen King look like Mrs:GaskelL . ' • ': ' - Hutson!s books are so full of spatteredrbrains and bodily fluids that I harboured .the naive hope that the assignment would turn into a voyage into a heart ofcdarkness. Imagine my disappointment when it only involved driving a few miles up the Ml and knocking on a door in jyiiltoii^eynes. Apart from ffis.passi6h.-for the more grisly type of heavy metal, our author was as normal as can be.
- That conjunction of- " weirdness; ' and banality.,. underpins "Garth Marerrghi's Fright . Kniglvt^^ iiesShowjhat. opene'd the short season"of award-winners from this year's Edinburgh Fringe. With his aviator glasses, his lurid imagination and his chronic inability to frame a decent sentence, Marenghi is a dead ringer for Hutson. Haunted by the terrible fear that the literary critics will never take him seriously, the great man unveils some of the. secrets of his craft in a playlet that zig-zags along with the help of some glorious coarse acting. Lugubrious to the last, Marenghi introduces us to the tortured Neil Hack, a horror writer struggling with his inner demons and a bad case of writer's block.
You could say that it is easy to parody the prose style of schlock horror fiction, but the extracts from the Marenghi - Hack oeuvre capture the preposterousness of it all without sinking into too much gore and guts. Redundant sentences are piled daintily on top of each other as we embark on a forced march through one dark and stormy night after another, pursued by cardboard ghouls — M.R. James as rewritten by Nigel Molesworth. The cod-surrealism does flag at times but the audience duly responded, and we are all left longing for the next chapter in Marenghi's autobiography. The second half of the double-bill , "Lee Mack's New Bits", simultaneously aimed
lower and higher. Lower, because Mack is working in a conventional sketch-show idiom that, F-words apart, would hardly be out of place in a Russ Abbott show. Higher, because in contrast to Marenghi's set-pieces , any duff notes will be seen as duff notes pure and simple rather than flashes of post-modernist irony. After a wobbly opening, Mack and his colleagues Catherine Tate and Dan Antopolski worked up an old-fashioned vaudeville head of steam. The Blair Witch parody already seems ancient and I never thought I would see an Irish jockey made into a figure of fun in this day and age. Mack, a skinny streak of nervous energy, somehow ! carries it off.

Full_text:
II : NEW NOVELS
Among new novels are FROM DAY TO DAY, by Ferdynand Goetel, translated ! from the Polish by Winifred Cooper
(Elkin M*Iathews, 7s. 6d.: net-); and STORIES WrrHOuT WoNiES; by Donn Byrne (Sampson Low, 7s. 6d. net).
" From Day to Day," the first specimen in English of the work of the Polish writer Ferdynand Gooetel, is introduced by Mr. Johin Galsworthy, whose explanatory note on the unusual method and construction of this novel should save the reader fiom a good deal of unnecessary bewilderment. MIr. Goetel gives us a novel and a diary, or rather alternating fragment-s of a novel and a diary, which are distinguished by being printed respectively in italics and Roman letters. The novel treats of the experiences of a Polish prisoner of var, who had fought wiith the Austrian armny and, having been captired bv the Russians, had been interned in Turkcstafi, where there happened to be a small colony of expatriated Poles. The prisoner in question is, or was, no other than the novelist himself- his novel, that is to say, is almost pure autobiographvy, in which he and tbe friend who was captured witlh him are disguised only by name, and in which the details of a love affair witl a Polish girl named Marttsia are reproduced withl tender fidelity. The diary is at once a comm,entary on the novel wmhih the novelist-diarist is writing and a record of domestic events years after the experiences recounted in the novel. Stanislaw, jlie Writer, is now living in Cracow, hardly on the best ef terms with his wife Zosia, simzilarly alienated from his former fellowprisoner, pursued by an emotional married woman wlho writes poetiy, and still obsessed by thoughts of the Polish girl in Turkestan. The cunning and I dexteritv with which the - two themes! are blended are much to be admired, and the final solution,in the pagesof the diary., of the problem posed, in the unfinished novel (vhich the author, wisely enough inD tho circumstances, throws up in despair). goes a long way towards justifying the element of eccentricity in the author's method. His story is not so striking dS his way of telling it ; but t-he performance. as a whole, is stimulating and well worth attention.
Readers of Lever will remember that Con Cregan, when invited to ivrite an account of French naval achievem-nents in Chinlese waters in the reign of King Louis Philippe, drew ample inspiration for an informiative and convincing article on the subject for his friend Paul de Min6rale's newvspaper from the contemplation of a willow-pattern plate. M;lr. Byrne, in these STORIES WITHOUT WOMEN, seems to have emulated his famous but fictional compatriot ; but, owing to the lapse of a century, the result is not quite as convincing or satisfactory. He tells a baker's dozen of stories (most. of vhich have women in
them), effective in themselves. sometimes' grave to the point of gloominess, sometimes gay. But nearly every one contains some irritating flawv, if not in the jewel, at
least in its setting. The author is not I happy in dressing his Orientals, or inl describing places vhich hc does not seem to have seen: ho is careless in some of his details and liiakes odd errors at times reminiscent of the magnificent disregard for time, space, and convention in dealing wvitlh foreign scenes and customs vhich used to characterize some of the earlier Aniciean cinematograph films.

From Day to Day, the first English specimen of the work of the Polish writer Rudolph Goolet, is introduced by Mr. Johon Galsworthy, whose explanation of the unusual method and construction of this novel should save the reader from a good deal of unnecessary bewilderment. Mr. Goethe gives us a novel and a diary, or rather, alternating fragments of a novels and a diaries, which are distinguished by being printed in italics and Roman letters. The novel consists of the experiences of a Polish prisoner of war, who had fought with the Austrian army and, having been captured by the Russians, had been interned in the Turkish city of Turkishstan, where there happened to be a small colony of expatriated Poles. The prisoner in question is, or was, no other than the novelist himself- his novel, that is to say, is almost pure autobiography, in which he and the friend who was captured with him are only disguised by name, and in which the details of a love affair with a Polish girl named Maria are reproduced with tenderness and fidelity. The diary is at once a chronicle of the novel which the novelist-diarist is writing and a record of the domestic events which follow after the experiences described in the novel. Stanislaw, like the Writer, is now living in Prague, hardly on the best terms with his wife, Zoe, who is similar to his former companion, and is pursuing an emotional wife who writes poetry, and is still obsessed by the thoughts of the Polish girl in Turkestan. The wit and the dexterity with which he writes with which the two themes are mixed are to be admired, and the final solution, in the pages of the diary, of the problem posed, in the unfinished novel which the author, in wise deeds in the circumstances, throws up in despair. It goes a long way toward justifying the eccentricity of the author's method. His story is not so striking as its telling, but the performance. As a whole, it is stimulating and well worth attention. Readers of Lady Lovelace will remember that Conway, when asked to write an account of French naval successes in Chinese waters during the reign of Louis XIV, drew ample inspiration for an informative and convincing article on the subject for his friend, Paul Revere, in the New England newspaper from the contemplation of a wall-paper pattern. Mr. Byrne, in these STORIES ABOUT WOMEN, seems to have emulated his famous but fictional counterpart, but owing to the lapse of time, the result is not quite as convincing or satisfactory. He tells a tale of three women, all of whom have some effect in him, and most of whom are not. sometimes to the point of gloominess, sometimes to death. But almost every book contains some annoying flaw, whether intentional or not, in the writing or in the setting. The author is not happy in dressing up his characters, or in describing places which he does not seem to have seen, or in making some of his details seem odd or reminiscent of the immense disregard for time, space, etc. dealing with the various scenes and customs which used to characterize the early American cinema.

Author: Johnson, Daniel
Title: Passion for the facts
Full_text:
Passion for the facts
Daniel Johnson surveys the most voluminous Christmas presents of all
Keats apostrophised "manna and dates, in argosy transferred from Fez", but some of us are no less addicted to the other kind of dates. If, as Bacon said, histor - ies make men wise, then chro - nology is the skeleton key to history, the aide memoire with - out which the past is a tale told by an ideologist. ' Odd, then, that one has had to scour second-hand book - shops to find the 20-year-old Chronology of World History. Now it has at last been repub - lished by Helicon in four vol - umes at £160 the set or £40 a volume. The Modern World: 1763-1992 has been updated, while its companions on the ancient, medieval and " expand - ing " worlds have lost none of their relevance. An invaluable repository of time past. History needs its temporal dimension , but it is no less meaningless without geogra - phy , and no library is complete without a good historical atlas. The Times Atlas of European History is cheap at £25. Pro - duced to the high standards one
expects from Times Books, it traces continental history as far as the Urals over three millen - nia , with enough text to orien - tate the reader without crowding the maps. The Dorling Kindersley World Reference Atlas costs more at £29.95 and cannot com - pete with the Times Atlases for the beauty of its maps. But it is a handy book for students of geo - graphy or international relat - ions , or for anybody who needs to know about a country at a glance. Each entry offers a col - ourful summary of the essential facts about the country in question. World History {Robert Hale £24.99) is "a dictionary of im - portant , people, places, and events, from ancient times to the present" . Edited by Bruce Wetterau, this slab of over a thousand pages compresses an entire chronology of each major nation into its entry. This cheap compendium will satisfy most gluttons for facts without hog - ging your bookshelves.
For longer mini-profiles , turn to the Cambridge Biographical Encyclo - pedia (Cambridge £29.95). Edited by David Crystal, this is an impressive work of enduring value; but I found it generally less informative than Magnus Magnussqn's older Chambers Biographical Dictionary (£35 hbk, also available in paper - back at only £17.99). More specialised but also more authoritative is the Hutchinson Dictionary of Sci - entific Biography (Helicon £50). Originally published in six volumes a decade ago, this one-volume edition has been edited by the redoubtable Roy Porter. The entries are scholarly and up to date, though the living scientists inevitably lead less colourful lives than the
boffins of earlier centuries. This is too expensive a work for most laymen, but secondary school libraries should have a copy. A Dictionary of Military History (Blackwell £35) is a French work edited by Andre Corvisier. It is admirably com - prehensive and offers useful bibliographies after each arti - cle . Though it has been revised for this English edition, there is an occasional hint of bias which may irritate some readers. I do not know whether John Childs, the Dictionary's British editor, examined the entry on Waterloo very careful - ly , but it certainly reads oddly: J The tactical errors of Napo - leon , who no longer had the vigour of youth, and the lack of initiative of his subordinates, in conjunction with the numerical inferiority of the French forces, explain this defeat which, so on - er or later, was inevitable." In other words: the Emperor (actu - ally only 45 at the time) and his marshals lost the battle; Wel-I
lington and Bliicher did not win it. That is nonsense. As for the inevitability of Napoleon's de - feat : he was outnumbered over - all , but not during the decisive engagement with Wellington and the disparity was some - what less than that between the French and the Allies at Auster - Iitz , say, when Bonaparte won. The Oxford Children's Book of Famous People is the flag - ship of a new series of children's reference books from OUP. At £20 for fewer than 400 pages, it is not very good value, though other titles are cheaper. How - ever , what bothered me most about this work was its cavalier treatment of the facts.
Take the entry on Adolf Hitler, a tricky subject for any teacher or parent. Hitler's early career gets too much space, yet the summary of his ideas does not even mention race. The story of Hitler's appointment as chancellor is badly garbled, while the claim that "millions of people were sent to concentra - tion camps" after 1933 is false: before 1939, the num - bers were in the thousands. No mention is made of appease - ment , and Hitler's wartime role is absurdly truncated. Other entries reveal similar flaws. Children deserve the same high standards that OUP normally maintain ,in their Continued on page XI
<NEWPAGE>
Reference books, continued from page VIII books for adults, and I cannot recommend it. Larousse, which dominates the French reference market, has come up with two cribs for literary pedants, both bargains at £25, useful for settling domes - tic disputes. The Dictionary of Writers is the most up-to-date work of its kind, and more international than the older Collins Biographical Dictio -
nary of English Literature, also £25. More fun is the Dictionary of Literary Characters. It will tell you whether it was Byron's Manfred who killed his daugh - ter by mistake, or whether Horace Walpole's Manfred in The Castle. of Otranto commit - ted incest with his sister. (It was the other way round.) Meeting the dramatis personae might persuade youngsters to read the works in which they appear; the same goes for adults, none of
whom will have read all the recent novels in this volume. The Cambridge Encyclope - dia , now available in a com - pletely revised second edition, is an excellent one-volume ency - clopedia , remarkably cheap at £29.95. It is less erudite than the more expensive Columbia En - cyclopedia , the current (fifth) edition of which costs more than twice as much (£65). The Cambridge undercuts its other rival, the Hutchinson Encyclo - pedia (1995 edition), at £35. The
Cambridge also offers more entries on more subjects and is more serious in tone.. But the gaudily illustrated Hutchinson is more reader-friendly . For schools and computer buffs, Hutchinson also publish - es the only British CD-ROM encyclopedia, the Hutchinson Multimedia Encyclopedia 1995 at £60. This is doubtless the shape of encyclopedias to come; but the price should fall when the CD-ROM market becomes more competitive.

The Oxford Children's Books of Famous People is the first in a new series of children's reference books from OUP. At 20 pages for less than 400 pages, it is not very good value, though other titles are cheaper. However, what bothers me most about this work is its clunky treatment of the facts. Take the entry on Adolf Hitler, a tricky subject for any teacher or parent. His early career gets too much space, and the summary of his ideas does not even mention race. The story of Hitler's appointment as chancellor is badly written, while the claim that millions of people were killed is unfounded. to concentration camps after 1933 is false, and before 1939, the numbers were in the thousands. No mention is made of appeasement, and Hitler's wartime role is absurdly truncated. Other entries reveal similar flaws. Children deserve the same high standards that adults do, and their continued use of the reference books is useful for settling domestic disputes. The Dictionary of Writers is the most up-to-date work of its kind, and more international than the older, more expensive American Dictionary of English Literature, also 25. More fun is the Dictionary of Literary Characters. It will tell you whether it was Byron who killed his daughter by mistake, or whether Horace Walpoles killed his sister in The Castle. Orson Welles committed adultery with his sister. It was the other way round. The drama of the protagonist might persuade youngsters to read the works in which they appear the same goes for adults, none of whom will have read all the recent novels in this volume. The Cambridge English Dictionary, now available in a completely revised second edition, is an excellent one-volume encyclopedia, remarkably cheap at $29.95. It is less erudite than the more expensive Columbia English Dictionary, the current fifth edition. 65. The Cambridge edition undercuts its rival, the Hutchinson Encyclopedia 1995 edition, by 35. The Cambridge also offers more entries on more subjects and is more serious in tone. But the Gaudily illustrated Hutton is more reader-friendly. For school children and computer buffs, Hutchinsons also publishes the only British CD-ROM encyclopaedia, the Hutton Multimedia Encyclopedia 1995, at 60. This is doubtlessly the shape of the encyclopedics to come, but the price should fall when the CD-ROM market becomes more competitive.

Author: Glendinning, Victoria
Title: Purging the boy in her books
Full_text:
Purging the boy in her books
T his is a startlingly good biography. On the face of it Daphne du Maurier, like many dedicated writ - ers , did not have an eventful life. She married an army officer, had three children, wrote best-selling novels — several of which have become classics — lived in Cornwall, and in later life was something of a recluse. She died in 1989. Margaret Forster's good luck is that Daphne's friends and family kept her letters, sometimes at Daphne's own request, for she intended to leave her testimony, and believed biography should tell the truth even though it might be "often hard for the family to take" . Daphne du Maurier's good luck is to have Margaret Forster as a biographer. There is piquancy in her having been educated at the same school—the County High School in Carlisle — as Tod, Daphne's governess. Tod was Daphne's confidante for years, and remained in - volved with the family until after Daph - ne 's own children had grown up. Forster shares something of that same sympath etic discretion and northern shrewdness. Daphne's father was the actor Gerald du Maurier, a world-class charmer who
two-timed his wife and loved his daugh - ters jealously and too much. He had longed for a son, and Daphne as a child not only wanted to be a boy but believed she really was one. Later she was attracted to both women and men; her early physical relationships were with a French schoolmistress and Carol Reed, the future film director. More important than either was being alone in the family's holiday house in Cornwall, and beginning to write. Her early stories were "fuelled by disgust" at the way men treated women. Daphne was extremely pretty in the English way, and her marriage to athletic good-looking Major Frederick Browning, known as Tommy, or Boy, seemed made in heaven. It was she who proposed and she, as her novels sold in their hundreds of thousands, who maintained their style of life, such as it was. The nurturing, maternal, home-making side of Daphne was non-existent . The house was icy, the food primitive. She loved her children, especially her son, but was a distant mother to the girls when they were little. Her elder daughter's nanny never had a single evening off for the first six months —- and when she was finally given one,
DAPHNE DU MAURIER By Margaret Forster Chatto8Windus,£17 .99
caring for the baby for a few hours reduced its parents to nervous prostration When a housemaid came to be inter - viewed , she thought the nanny was Mrs Browning, and that Mrs Browning was a visitor, she seemed so detached. Yet Daphne's whole life was centred on her home which was, for 25 years, Menabilly — the Manderley of Rebecca. The second world war showed up the cracks in the marriage. Tommy had a brave and distinguished war career, ending up as Mountbatten's right-hand man, and was knighted in 1946. In spite of a wartime liaison of her own, she had longed for his return. Somehow they could not pick up the pieces. He was inhibited and exhausted, and she was depressed by the anti-climax . A couple of years later Daphne, aged forty, was infatuated, like a romantic boy, with Ellen Doubleday the wife of her American publisher. Tommy, mean -
while , became Comptroller to the house - hold of HRH Princess Elizabeth and had to be in London. Daphne then fell in love less chastely with Gertrude Lawrence, one of her father's last mistresses, who was playing the lead in Daphne's play September Tide, which was really about Ellen Doubleday. All rather complicated. Tommy drank too much, sailed his boat at weekends and found his own consolat - ions in female form. He and Daphne were often unhappy, both sometimes on the verge of mental breakdown. They still loved one another in a deep, hopeless way and kept up a united front for outsiders and on occasions such as visits to Balmoral. People still saw Sir Frederick and Lady Browning as the ideal couple. Daphne hated "the L-word" — lesbian — and thought of herself as a " half - breed ", and as having a No 1 self, which the world saw, and a No 2 self, who was a "boy-in-a-box" and the one who did the writing. Her tragedy was that the " boy - in - the - box " faded after Gertrude's death and as Daphne grew older; without him it was harder to find the impetus for fiction. Her work grew more macabre. After Tommy's death her widowhood seems sad.
Daphne du Mauner was articulate in her private letters about her dual self and about the specific relationships or crises which she "purged" in her fictions. Rebecca, for example, was sparked off by her jealousy of her husband's former fiancee. The works stand on their own and need no subtexts. But there always was one, and those who protest against biographers reading the life into the work and the work through the life are, in this case at least, knocked clean out of court. Because Daphne wrote so eloquently about herself, virtually all Forster has to do in order to reveal the complexities is to quote, though she makes an excursion into hypothesis about the sexual death of the marriage. I thought, at first, that Forster's authorial reticence was excessive. She does not address the' question of whether Daphne was interfered with by her crazily possessive and very hands-on father, though every reader must wonder. She glides over Daphne's physical affair with Gertrude in such a way that it would be possible to miss it. But afterwards these matters resonate in.the mind with an ambiguity that may well reflect the reality. It is all extremely well-judged .
Victoria Glendinning

Because Daphne wrote so eloquently about herself, almost all that Forster has to do in order to reveal the complexities is to quote, though she makes an occasional expedition into the abyss of the dead. I thought, at first, that Forster's authorial reticence was excessive. She does not address the question of whether Daphne was interfering with her by being so crass and possessive as her father, though every reader must wonder. She glides over Daphne's physical affair with Gloria in such a way that it would be impossible to miss it. But after all, these matters resonate in the mind with an ambiguity that may well reflect the reality. It is all extremely well-judged. Victoria Glendinning

Title: By English Waters
Full_text:
BY ENGLISH WATERS
ANGLERS' BACKGROUND
THE ANGLER's ENGLAND. By PATRICK
CHALMERS. Seeley Service. 8s. 6d.
The new volume of the "English Scene" series is devoted to fishing in English waters, fresh and salt. And Mr. Patrick Chalmers, looking at the various "Aspects" of fishing in England, notes that while, in the artistic " Aspect," John Leech has given us both a classic fishing figure in Mr. Briggs, and a classic hunting one in Jorrocks, there are many classic hunting novels on the bookshelf, but no classic fishing novel. This is surprising but true. All the same, the literature of hunting cannot compare with the literature of fishing. From the " Book of St. Albans," which includes both but extols fishing, through Izaak Walton. down to Charles Kingsley, Froude, Andrew Lang, Lord Grey of Fallodon, and even- later, much has been written on the sport of angling which can properly be classed as good literature; and Mr. Chalmers, himself a fishing writer of authority and repute, gives us a short list of his favourites.
Every fisherman makes his own list- to which this book, wiihout doubt, will be added. For Mr. Chalmers not only, writes with all the zest of an enthusiast, he gives us also many good stories, much research to prove Shakespeare's knowledge of angling, and much verse of others, and of his own-his sporting songs are famousboth new and old. He writes with special knowledge of Thames fishing, both for trout and for "coarse" fish which, he rightly says, require an even higher form of art than is necessary for salmon and trout; though, as illustrating the "English Aspect," he chooses, and describes lovingly, a golden day on the Test with the dry-fly. And if for most of his descriptions of sport with salmon and seatrout he goes to Scottish memories and not to Wye or Usk, Dart or Tamar, he can plead that Charles Kingsley, most English of writers, preferred a Highland salmon-river to any other. Most English fishermen will agree with him. At any rate, he writes so charmingly that they will forgive him.

Title: New Novels

NEW NOVELS
TERRORISTS IN MACEDONIA
NIGHT OVER THE EAST. - Translated and
Adapted from the German by EDWIN and WILLA MUIR. Sheed and Ward. 7s. 6d.
There may be good reasons for withholding from the reader any information about the author of this novel, of which the setting is South-Eastern Europe and the principal episodes are concerned with the Macedonian terrorist organization known as Imro; but it would have been helpful to know the precise extent of "' adaptation " which the translators have found necessary or desirable. It is an extraordinary piece of wvork, written with furious energy and with uncommon dialectical skill in the Catholic standpoint, entirely melodramatic in style, yet both illuminating and persuasive.
'We arrive -at South-Eastern Europe by way of Finland, where Albert, Baron von Kloibner, a peculiarly vehement Hungarian aristocrat, has retired after the War in order to nurse the most inspissated of glooms. His life among the Lapps of the Murman coast is described vividly enough, but the fun does not begin in earnest until he is back in Budapest, where the brilliantly rhapsodical Tom O'Flanagan awaits him. This is an indomitable adventurer of the new school, who, had smuggled himself into Soviet Russia and outwitted the Cheka, hatched revolutions in South America, sold the plans of Indian fortresses, and so on. His greatest and last love is Macedonia"; his mortal 'foe is Belgrade, with its orthodoxy and Freemasonry and even worse things in the background. Albert, torn between an old aristocratic love and a new aristocratic love-the voluble strain of contempt for the undifferentiated mass is not without its interest-is pressed into the service of Imro, and wanders between Budapest, Sofia, and Vienna-while Tom and the immensely efficient Bulgarian terrorist, Krum Daneff, get down to work. He alone survives, a somewhat transcendental Catholic self-condemned to exile in Lapland.
CREED. By MARGIAD EvANs. Oxford:
Blackwell. 7s. 6d.
"I begin to write, relying on the force and fine senses of each moment," announces Miss Evans in a brief preface. "That will be my strength.
What I offer you as reading is real, though I outstrip each page and at the end am different." It is her strength, and her offering is real; we may agree, even though the "difference" she either fears or, it may be, hopes for, is not very evident. Her characters change, some of them, in their own strange ways, but it is a transformation, inherent from the very first chapter. There 'Francis Dollbright, who walks in the fear of a merciless God, cries out upon one who holds a gentler view; before the end he has himself cast off the burden of his fear in acceptance of that same view, which would seem to be very much the author's also. This progress towards release, which begins with a yet deeper descent towards terror, is the story's main subject; but other persons are grouped about Dollbrighta lodger, a girl, and her lover-who similarly struggle in desperate toils. These characters, drowning in their fears and despairs, -determine the book's somewhat nightmare quality, its intensitv, its strangeness, so marked that the Welshborder town of Chepsford, where all' takes place, itself seems dreamlike, wavering yet more real than any daylight world. The personal nature of Miss Evans's vision leads her up some odd alleys; her power as a writer is undeniable.
THE GREEN LION. By FRANCIS HACKETrT.
Nicholson and Watson. 7s. 6d.
Mr. Francis Hackett is better known in America than in this country, where his highly coloured studies in history have
been subjected to severe criticism. But i this novel of Irish life during Pamnell's last campaign is direct, vigorous and devoid of stylistic trappings. Mr. Hackett is primarily interested in the social, religious, and political factors which have gone to the making of modern Ireland. But he is an e?cellent storyteller and his account of the childhood and schooldays of Jerry Coyne is full of authentic incident and has a freshness of its own. The story mainly takes place in the historic but decayed city of Kilkenny, with its memories of Berkeley, Congreve and Swift.
Jerry lives with his uncle, who 'is the editor of a provincial newspaper,' and his' earliest impressions, therefore, are of the furious political factions of the time and the rising force of. clericalism.' Jerry's progress from convent infant class to Christian Brothers and Jesuit residential college is in itself a summary of the Irish educational system. Mr. Hackett appears to be an uncompromising opponent of celibate education, and his main purpose is to show its deleterious effect on the national character. But he avoids morbidity and makes his young hero a normal healthy boy.
THE ROAD AND THE WOOD. By JOHN
OWEN. Macmillan. 7s. 6d.
So long as Mr. Owen is dealing with the country folk of the Suffolk village where the scene of his novel is laid the pages of' this novel are attractive and convincing. Ephraim Power, the philosophical tramp, with his mongrel dog, and his strange friend Dave Alullins, whose muddled wits are lit by a ray of religious illumination, are well described and their communings in Suffolk dialect admirably rendered. Unfortunately other parts of the novel are less convincing than Dave's institution of solitary worship in his woodland temple. The train of rather melodramatic circumstance whereby a clever doctor has to bring his tortured, remorseful soul to be healed by the simDle rustic loon strikes the reader as an artificial construction which is not improved by the author's rather desperate attempt to interest him il ' the doctor's psychological case. A fatal motor accident begins the train of events, and another one has to end it. What happens in the wood is better than what happens on the road.

Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS.
Among the novels of the week are THE PROMISED LAND, by Sir Gilbert Parker (Cassell, 7s. 6d. net); A BROOD OF DUCKLLNGS, by Frank Swinnerton (Hutclhinson, 7s. 6d. net); and YotiTH RIDES Our, by Beatrice Kean Seymour (Chapman and Hall, 7s. 6d. net).
Sir Gilbert Parker has felt himself inspired to retell the stories of Saul and David, Kings of Israel. So far as the narrative in the Books of Samuel and Kings is explicit hc keeps strictly to it, as he keeps to the magnificent phraseology of the Authorized Versidn. His own additions, apart from those of accurate scenic description, are somewhat below the magnificences of the ancient chronicle. There are readers, no doubt, who will appreciate Sir Gilbert's amplification of details, and be grateful to him for his presentations of the female characters, such as Michal, Leah, and above all Bathsheba; but we doubt if their previous ideas of the great heroic characters, Saul, Samuel, David, and Jonathan, will receive any important quickening from this praiseworthy but rather solemn gloss on a story which, in England, is still a household word.
Mr. Frank Swinnerton has written what might be called a mystery story of the emotions. Like the author of a detective novel, Mr. Swinnerton sows his pages with false clues, and it is not until the last few pages of a by no means slhort book that the reader knows who is in love with Catherine and who is in love with Rhoda. Catherine and Rhoda are the two daughters of Ferdinand Meadows, the twin Cordelias of a mild and sensitive Lear. The greater part of the book is taken up with long and tortuous conversations on the possible relationships of the characters. Ferdinand is terrified that Catherine, his elder, quieter, and less emotional daughter, is in love with Jabez Talbot, an earnest North-country Socialist, whose abruptness is a perpetual agony to him, but it is Rhoda, the younger, more volatile girl, about whom he had separate but no less dreadful fears, who eventually marries Jabez.
" Youth Rides Out " is the story of an unsuccessful marriage. Lindsay Bordon, who inherited a certain idealistic asceticism and a strong will, from his father, fals in love with the lovely CamiUa Neale, aged 19. Camilla's doting father is a rich manufacturer of biscuits, and has never thwarted her happiness. Camilla gets her penniless lover, whose chosen profession is that of veterinary surgeon in Liverpool; and in getting him she meant to get him wholly. Here she failed. Love, for Camilla, meant amorous dalliance in a life of ease, and she trusted in her power to use passion as the means of weaning Lindsay from a life of poverty and strenuous endeavour and of brioging him into the opulent Neale world. The major part of this novel is a detailed description of the battle between Lindsay Bordon's will and the Neale family. It is cleveirly done with a wealth of detail of the domestic kind.

Author: Null
Title: A New Book On Billiards
Full_text:
A NEW BOOK ON
BILLI ARDS.
PLEA FOR SIMPLICITY.
HOW TO PLAY BrI.Lianws. By Tom NEW-
mAN. (Methuen. Ss. 6d.)
*Most people have at one time or another had their inaccuracy in the striking of a billiard ball illustrated by a simple method. This consists in placing the ball on the centre spot of the balk line, aiming straight up the table over the line of spots, and keeping the tip of the cue still after the ball has been struck. If the ball has been accurately struck it should hit the tip of the cue on the return journey, but it is a humiliating fact that it generally does nothing of the sort. Nexwman says that he would like his pupils "to practise that solo-ball shot for an hour or two every day for at least a month before reading another word of mv book "; but let not the reader take fright, for he admits, rather wistfully, that this is too much to ask. His advice is quoted only to give a very faint notion of the hard labour that a professional billiard player must undergo, and also to show that the amateur who is to get full value from professional instruction needs a table of his own and abundant leisure.
Even for those, however, who have not these advantages, the Champion has written an interesting and helpful book. It is at once admirably simple and detailed. Not only does Newman write in a plain, direct way, but he brushes aside some of those knowing and mysterious complexities both of language and execution which the amateur loves. It is not till nearly half-way through the book that he will allow his pupil to attempt anything beyond hitting the ball plumb in the middle. About page 90 he introduces side with the playing of a jenny, and lets himself indulge in a brief rhapsody on the " side-laden ball sizzling into the pocket"; ;but, even so, he is very austere.
CUE-CONTACTS.
The terms "check" and "running" side he would "like to cut clean out of the billiard vocabulary " ; right and left are good enough for him, and he is down like a hundred of bricks on those who advise ".a little bit of top" or "a little bit of side " for strokes which are " legitimately wvithin the scope of plain-ball strikinz." HIe gives a very instructive diagram sbowving five " cue-contacts " on the ball. The first is, of course, the central contact, and the others are those for full right-hand side, full left-hand side, full top, and full screw. Newman assures his pupil that he will play very good billiards indeed if he never worries much about any others, and adds that he himself "might easily play for days on end in first-class professional billiards without ever utilizing more side, top, or screw than is obtainable from these cue-contacts."
So much for Newman's severe simplicity, and a very good example of his care for detail is to be found in his advice as to stance. Premising that he is himself 5ft. 9in., with arms rather long for his height, and that the ball is on the centre spot of the balk line, and that he proposes to play it straight up the table, he gives the exact distance in inches between the face of the balk cushion and his two feet respectively. Similarly, he measures the distance between the knuckle of the forefinger of his bridge hand and the balk line. Thus the student, making allowances for difference 'in physique, can place himself as nearly as may be exactly in the champion's attitude before he sets, out to learn to swing his cue. All through the book similar measurements are given, and there is nothing vague and undecided, nothing that is not clean cut.
Another famous billiard player, Mr. Sidney Fry, has lately advised amateurs to look at the cue ball when making a stroke. Newman is not of this school. He wants us to look at the object ball, and says that he himself, besides doing this, " visualizes the cotnmencement of the line of departure of the cue ball immediately after ball-to-ball contact in the case of a losing hazard or, cannon, or of the object ball in the case of a winning hazard." The two great men do not agree-that is clear -but Mr. Fry admits that the professionals are so perfect in cue delivery that they can afford to look at the object ball, whereas the average amateur is anything but perfect, and is apt to move his body. To keep the eye on the cue ball does surely help towards keeping the body from that fatal jack-in-the-box movement.
AN ILL-JUDGED STROKE.
It is amusing to turn for a moment from Newman's book to that of Mr. Edward Russell Mardon, written in 1844. It was in that year that Mr. Mardon played, at the great Kentfield's rooms at Brighton, a match of 500 up against a certain Mr. Porker, who gave him a start of 25. Mr. Porker reached 496: -Mr. Mardon, a very Inman of defensive tactics, gave a miss: Mr. Porker rashly let fly at the red ball, whereupon Mr. Mardon, amid frenzied excitement, ran out with 25 unfinished. He was so much impressed bv this performance that he wrote a book all about it. Possibly he was rather a ridiculous old gentleman: he was fond of talking about himself and of the noble earls and marquises with whom he played, but he wrote very good sense, for all that. " Simplehazard striking free from all gallery claptrap attraction, and from every kind of useless embellishment "-that was his motto. It was his desire " to induce those already enamoured of the pursuit to abandon the uncertain, dashing style of game, and to adopt one based on simplicity of action combined with proper strength."
Mr. Mardon, though he despised a "florid hazard striker." was rather a florid writer, and Newman is a simple, straightforward one, but their sentiments are the same. If billiards be played on the asphodel, it is pleasanat to picture M. Mardon enjoying himself by setting out the balls as in Newman's diagrams. He may even draw the attention of his late adversary to them. " Ah, my dear sir," he will say, " here is a very sensible young man. You should read what he says. He agrees with me entirely. And you know, my dear Mr. Porker, you never should have made that ill-judged and temerarious stroke at the red ball."

Memoirs are made of this
Lost sisters, damaged fathers, mad husbands - everybody with a family has a tale to tell. But Bel Mooney wonders if their stories are really fact or fiction
THE TITLE OF MARY LOUDON'S last book offers insight into the complexity of memoir. Secrets and Lives was an oral history of the people of Wantage in the Studs Terkel tradition. Yet the fact that the brain automatically supplies "lies" instead of "lives" is a reminder of the central problem of life-writing. As the most ordinary lives contain secrets, truth is always a relative stranger — belonging to no one yet claimed by the imagination, with its whisper of "what if? Six volumes of memoir sit on my desk, of which two are outstanding, and all compulsively readable. Some sort of family dysfunction is the sine qua non for each. Loudon's own Relative Stranger sets out to give "a life after death" to her older, schizophrenic sister who took on a male identity; John Burnside's A Lie About My Father evokes "the dark, bruised presence" of the damaged father who damaged his son. Mother Country by Jeremy Harding is the poignantly understated tale of two mothers, natural and adoptive — "real and imagined"; while Horatio Clare writes the biography of a divorce in pellucid prose. Keeping Mum (Brian Thompson) and A Secret Madness (Elaine Bass ) dissect two bizarre marriages in the sepia hues of 1940s and 1950s austerity. Such summings-up are inevitably simplistic; each memoir is a complex universe in itself, and all employ some ofthe narrative methods ofthe novel. Ten years ago, such life stories would probably have been seen through the prism of fiction: the personal universalised by art — even at the level of the roman a clef. Today "real" life is easier to market: memoir is the form for our time. Mary Loudon's opening sentence launches briskly into shock: "On the 27th January 2001, while I was skiing fast down a mountain in France, my sister Catherine was dying slowly in England; in a hospital I didn't know she had been admitted to, from a cancer I didn't know she had, under an identity I had no idea existed." Her quest was to find answers: "I could not let her go without an effort. I did not want to claim her, only to
locate her... I wanted to find... the family member we had lost and preserve some of her essence for good." This she achieves triumphantly with a novelist's eye for detail — even nudging the heartbreaking chaos of her sister's terrible flat towards the transforming beauty of still life. Catherine Loudon lived her final years as a man, and Mary's efforts to understand why leads her into encounters with some extraordinary characters, among them Mr Carpenter, the mortuary technician who displays respect and grace; Karen the Care Worker who tells how "Stevie" played the piano; George from the corner shop whose care in the simple ways of sandwiches and tobacco prompts an epiphany about human kindness worthy ofthe author of Middlemarch: "In every village, every town, every city and every country there are people like George doing kind, decent, selfless things simply because to do those things is right." Vivid, true and moving. This is memoir as painstaking investigation: Loudon's conversations are recorded, and she does not speculate, but alternates her quest with telling anecdote and (most sad) the 1973 diary of their father, who travelled fruitlessly to India to bring his mentally ill daughter home. Gradually, as Cathy's character is rounded out and her damaged life given dignity and meaning, Loudon is changed too, as if the journey towards her lost sister adds new dimensions of complexity and humility to her own life. Behind this is another voice — that of the cool writer for whom everything is grist and method is all: "Objectifying an experience is part of the distillation necessary to turn it into something readable..." Sentences themselves impose order: the act of writing is as healing as the quest itself. The poet and novelist John Burnside quotes a line from Marguerite Duras which translates as: "It is the unknown you carry within — to write, it's that or nothing." He takes the idea of memoir as self-discovery a stage further than
