Loudon, not flinching from his own drug abuse, psychosis and estrangement from the bullying, inadequate father who ruined his ufe—and arguably created the writer. Burnside lays down a challenge in the Lie of his title and his first statement: "This book is best treated as a work of fiction." He consciously conjures up stories ("I can imagine him so easily in the telling. ..") about the father who lied so much about his own background that Burnside did not know until after his death that he had been left on a doorstep in West Fife. This account of a failed father-son relationship is written with extraordinary beauty and insight, repeatedly opening Chinese boxes of meaning: "A photograph, a family story, the recollections of some old-timer at a wedding or funeral, are works of art, not facts", and "However hard you try to avoid it, fatherhood is... something that is not only told to, but told by, others." His sophisticated sensibility occasionally sounds a false note, as when Father takes them to a cut-price warehouse for bargains. "When... we picked out what we wanted, I was struck by the sadness of our possessions... worthless, ill-made objects..." The child clutching the cheap tennis racket is only 10, so
when Burnside recalls being "sad and ashamed" this is surely "all after the fact, all construction". He knows that the distinction between transformation and invention is fine, so after describing the solitary life of the father he did not see, he hauls us back to reality: "I'm sure my father felt these things—but these are my words, and this is the real lie about my father. I cannot talk about him without talking about myself, just as I can never look at myself in the mirror without seeing his face." His is a profound meditation on the life of the spirit, and all the shadows we carry in our hearts. Life-writing is a yardstick by which you can measure your own story, offering insight and consolation in equal measure. When James Frey's bestselling memoir, A Million Little Pieces, was revealed to be largely fiction, it sparked this riposte from his publisher, Nan Talese. "Memoir is personal recollection. It is not absolute fact. It's how one remembers what happened." But what if it happened before you were born? Horatio Clare tackles this head-on in his account of his parents' doomed 1960s dream of family life on a bleak Welsh hill farm. He has reconstructed from his parents' stories and diaries "and supplied the rest from my imagina-
tion". Why? "I needed to try to see the world as it was then, through the eyes of a young couple who tried to make it turn for them. I hoped, by telling the story, to understand it better." Loudon and Burnside are breathing life into the dead but Clare's subjects are living, and he is aware ofthe pitfalls: "I fear in its intrusion and exposure this book may distress its subjects, the people I love most." The requirement that memoir must read like fiction can lead to absurdity. Clare apparently recalls verbatim an exchange with his father when he was 6, and Elaine Bass tells the bleak story of her postwar marriage to a man with Obsessive Compulsive Disorder in reams of direct speech, that are in the end exasperating and make the suspension of disbelief impossible. The press release says that this "reads like a novel", and I found myself wishing that Mrs Bass, who is 84, had done a Mary Wesley and told her story as fiction, instead of allowing it to fall between two stools. But had she done so she would have been lucky to find a publisher. Similarly Brian Thompson's wonderful wartime childhood is apparently told with the help of Mary Loudon's taperecorder, the conversations between the 9-year-old and his dysfunctional Yank-loving mum as vivid as screenplay. The line between fact and fiction is thoroughly blurred. As Jeremy Harding says, "wild conjecture is always ready to fill the gaps". Does it matter? We live in a culture where phrases such as "virtual reality" and "creative nonfiction" have meaning, and where the television schedules are dominated by flyon-the-wall and confessional. Dave Peltzer has perfected the genre of memoir as self-harm, and for every Angela's Ashes there is a refutation by an aggrieved sibling. The internet is awash with bloggers' lives and recently Blake Morrison (master ofthe "intrusive" memoir) said on Radio 4 that more lives of ordinary people should be recorded. With luck one or two will contain literary gems like this from Harding: "There was a trace of dusk about the early afternoon on Ladbroke Grove. As the cloud let up, a brief burst of sunlight raked a No 52 bus. The inside of the lower deck glowed like a church, as though each passenger had lit a spill and held it up at the window." Title: Best seller
Full_text:
"Best ' seller
I Now Barabbas Was a Rotter
By Brian Masters
(Hamish. Harw4lton, £6.95)
Marie Corelli was a startling and worrying phenomenon: a writer whose books far and away outsold everyone's else's, who made well' over £15,000 a year from them round about the turn of the century, and who was the second most famous woman in England. But, as everyone knows, her novels were tosh, and the vituperation they attracted from the critics is unmatched.
- Brian Masters has researched her life with impeccable thoroughness, chasing her letters to Detroit, Claremont and Urbana and an old suitcase in a Stratford outhouse, tracking down her famous gondola to a film studio prop-man's yard, transcribing accounts. *of this libel action and that vendetta, discovering her training her dog to destroy all bad, notices and describing as "impertinence)" an income tax inspector's request for a sight of her royalty statenments.
She was, quite obviously, a monstre sacre of almost unparalleled a,wfulness: proud, complacent, vain, snobbish, a fearful liar, a constant torment to her publishers, ungrateful to those who befriended and admired her, spitting and fuming' at those who ignored her. But in the end, she was after all an ' immeasurably ' sad woman, desperately lonelv anid basically insecure, cursed by the possession of an insatiable artistic instinct but 'only the very faintest talent.
It is here that Mr Masters fails her and his readers. He writes as noisily us Corelli berself, crying down her every action and instinct, her every book, belittling even her relatively few generous instinctsher tactless attempts to help the starving Ouida, her cheque to the mother of an insane man who apparently tried to assassinate her. While this is certainly a fascinating and highly readable biography, it would have been a great dealbetter if the author could have summoned a little more svmpathy for his subject.
Time and again his case is weakened by the stridency of his comment (one would have thought someone capable of a title as meaningless as Now Barabbas Was a Rotter wvould throw his own stones more carefully). Finally, he drives us into Corelli's arms-the last place one would want to be; one's heart bleeds for the unfortunate Arthur Severn, a second-rate artist with whom, at the age of 56, the novelist fell violently bat alas platonically in love. Even _Mr Masters seems touched bv the impossibility of Corelli in love: Malvolio has nothing on her. But it is not until the penultimate chapter, in which he examines her novels-The Sorrows of Satan, The Mighty Atom and the rest-with more moderate and careful attention, that there are signs of how much better a book this could have been.
Derek Parker'

But, as everyone knows, her novels were toss ups, and the vitriol they attracted from the critics was unmatched. -Brian James has researched her life with impeccable thoroughness, chasing down her letters to Detroit, Claremont and Updike in an old suitcase in a Stratford outhouse, tracking down her famous gondola to a film studio prop-man's yard, and transcribing her account of this libel and its vendetta, discovering her training her dog to destroy all bad notices, and describing in great detail an income tax inspector's request for a sight of her royalty statements. She was, quite obviously, a woman of extraordinary charm, an almost unremarkable wfulness, a proud, vain, snobbish, frightful Lillie, a constant torment to her publishers, ungrateful to those who befriended and admired her, and spitting and fuming at those who ignored her. But in the end, she was an immeasurably sad woman, deeply alone and insecure, smothered by the possession of an insatiable artistic instinct but only the very slightest talent. It is here that Mr. James fails his readers. He writes as vociferously as anyone else, describing her every action and instinct, her every book, her even her relatively few generous instincts, her tacitless attempts to help the poor, her cheques to the mother of an insane man who apparently tried to assassinate her. While this is certainly a fascinating and highly readable biography, it would have been a great deal better if the author could have summoned could have summoned a little more sympathy for his subject. And time and again this case is weakened by the stridentness of his criticism: one would have thought someone capable of a title such as Now Babbage Was a Rabbit would have tossed his own stones more carefully. Finally, he drives us into Corelli's arms--the last place one would want to be one's heart bleeds for the unfortunate Arthur Severn, a second-rate artist with whom, at the age of 56, the novelist fell deeply but surprisingly romantically in love. Even Mr. James seems troubled by the impossibility of Corelli being in love with Marlowe. But it is not until the penultimate chapter, in which he examines his novels--The Sorrows of Saint Mark, The Mighty Atom and the Rest--with more moderate and careful attention, that there are signs of how much better a book this could have been.

NEW NOVELS
18TH-CENTURY ITALY
THE SON OF MARIETrA. By JOHAN
FABRICIUS. Translated from the Dutch *by IRENE CLEPHANi and DAVID HALLETh (Gollancz. 9s. 6d.)
Long before the reader has reached the last of these 1,053 pages it has become sufficiently plain that its prodigious length is not the most remarkable thing about this novel of eighteenth-century Italy. The supreme gift of the creative imagination, for which so bold and ambitious a venture encourages the hope at the outset, is not to be discovered here; but this is an astonishingly well sustained piece of story-telling, rich in character and in the excitement of the drama of incident.
For two-thirds of the book the scene is the old episcopal town of Todi, where one of the women belonging to a troupe ot travelling players abandons her child, 'the infant Marietta,'who is brought up by a very prince of rascals among innkeepers. At the convent where she flies for protec-' tion at the age of 13 the child wins the attention of the new Bishop of Todi, an admirable study of the subtle and erring ecclesiastic of Venetian society. Though Monsignore is resolved to save his soul by marrying Marietta to the boy who adores her, the child which she eventually bears in Rome is his, not her husband's. A climax is reached in the Bishop's unpremeditated yielding to passion.
The second part describes Benedetto's childhood in Todi, and is likewise marked by unusual psychological penetration. He is a strange, sombre'little boy, untouchecr by the motives and passions of his kind. The evil to which he is as it were predestined is suggested with notable skill and. dramatic force. In the third and last part of-the novel, the scene of which is Venice,' where he has fled with the jewels with' which' a-rich old lady was buried in the family vault, Benedetto struggles in vain against his destiny, which, in Novalis's phraserjischaracter:'Notfeven MonsTgnore can save him from the scaffold, since in the end the youth has no. further, desire to live. It is a crowded and vivid and .firmly disciplined story, which holds the reader's respect and admiration' all through.
IN THE SECOND YEAR. By STORM JAMESON.
Cassell. 7s. 6d..
In her new novel Miss Storm Jameson takes us forward to 1940, to an England destroyed by a dictatorship. The writers '~and thinkers seem' to' be populating prisbn camps where they are being taught social behaviour by starvation and flogging, while the few who escape prison are in risk of brutal murder or suicide. The country is in dire poverty; food is scarce except among the oligarchy ; even the dictators murder each other judicially.
It is impossible not to recognize the art with which Miss Jameson describes her prisons and her murders; but it is in the psychology of the English people and their imagined tyrants that she seems to go completely astray and to lose the sense of reality which we have always expected of her since-her 'stories of Yorkshire shipyards and their workers. A book such as this cannot be judged purely as a work of art; it is too frankly a sincere and passionate piece of propaganda. If Miss Jameson's horror of dictatorships in other lands has hurt her so badly that she felt she must make a protest it would have been wiser to place the story in some couiritiy where things like these may be possible; in taking England for her biackground she has stultified her work.

has returned.to the 18th-century setting of an earlier bestseller, Chatterton. , Mingling fact and fiction to entirely plausible effect, The Lambs of London is set in the mid-1790s, when Charles Lamb, then a few years into what was to be a 30-year career at the East India Company, was recovering from a nervous breakdown. Nursing him was his beloved sister, Mary — herself on the verge of the fit of insanity that was td cause her, a year or two later, to murder their mother. Among the other characters who people this vividly realised world is the antiquarian bookseller and sometime forger William Ireland. The platonic but intense romance between the latter and Mary Lamb is the focus of the story, which ends — as, indeed, does the love affair — when Ireland is unmasked as a fraud and Mary, distracted by grief, commits the terrible crime for which she remains notorious. The author's re-creation of these events is masterly. His feeling for the language of his chosen period is as sharp as one has come to expect. But it is in the realisation of the characters — poor, troubled Mary and her dipsomaniac sibling; gifted, over-reaching Ireland, and a host of others — that Ackroyd excels. Tender, funny and humane, this is as good as anything he has written.

Almost anything that is past may claim the title of history. Historians have commandeered the word for their owvn province, but what are their parliamen.s and dynasties, their campaigns. defeats. and empires without the multifarious private man ? It is he. with his small ejaculations, his jotting in a notebook how Lizzie'; dress was yellow or the headsman's axe not sharp. who gives depth to the recurring pageants of his rulers. NEW NOVELS
IT'S A BATTLEFIELD. By GRAHAM GREENE.
(Hcinemann. 7s. 6d. net.)
It's a Battlefield " is an indictment of the institutions of the day and a denial that they and the people affected by. them are governed by any intelligible principle. Mr. Graham Greene, the author, conceives London as a battlefield such as Inkerman was in the description of Kinglake-a -nist-enshrouded battlefield in which each little group of soldiers fights its own fight without reference to any general plan and without knowledge of the procedure of any other group. He emphasizes the futility of human endeavour by exhibiting it as controlled by lifeless machines such as factories and the apparatus associated with Justice-which to' him is a meaningless abstraction.
Justice proposes to hang one Drover who killed a policeman in a riot after a Communist meeting. Drover, who happened to have with him the knife of his trade, was defending his wife, whom the policeman was about to bludgeon. Various movements for a reprieve are handled in a way to illustrate human selfishness and impotence. Being concerned primarily with hysterical states of mind, Mr. Greene does not have to reckon with the probabilities in providing his outcome -that which he selects being the most repugnant possible to those affected. He is so intransigent in his distaste for the existing order that when he has occasion for a bus it has to be a pirate bus. But he has nothing to offer in exchange; though he belabours captains and rulers, be keeps his most envenomed shafts for the " reds "; for instance, for that advanced economist Mr. Surrogate, who "resnted Drover's intrusion as an individual to be saved and not a sacrifice to be decked for the altar."
A MODERN TRAGEDY. BY PHYLLIS
BENTLEY. (Gollancz. 8s. 6d. net.)
Miss Bentley has ambitiously essayed a difficult and complicated theme as the subject: of her second long novel, "A Modern Tragedy,'" by giving us a new version of the fraudulent company promoter. It is a new version because she has pitched' her scene in the West Riding of Yorkshire, and Tasker, her chief figure, is primarily a manufacturer of woollen goods, who becomes involved in juggling with his various companies and properties owing to the depressing influence of the 'Great Slump. The victim in whom we are mainly interested is a young man called Walter Haigh-not a very happy creation -whom Tasker, for his own purposes, lifts out of obscurity in order to make him the manager of a dyeing and cloth-finishing factory. Miss Bentley has apparently studied the processes of woollen manufacture at first hand, but her treatment of the methods of high finance lacks that air of assurance which brings to the reader the comfortable conviction that precisely thus and thus the thing could have happened.

A few decades hence, perhaps, some student of fiction will be able to discern that all these three books date from the nineteen-twenties. At present a striking difference among a hundred differences between them is that only one of them plainly dates. It might be said, roughly, that Mr. Michael Sadleirs novel is -of no time; Mr. Goldring's novel of the present time; Miss Mayne's stories of all time. And this is true of manner as well as of aubject. NO doubt Miss lMayne could not, or would not, have written her stories just so before, say, the year 1890; but, unless we claim that subtlety was absent from the female heart and brain before our own day, Miss Mayne's peculiar way of setting that subtlety before us is the only dated thing in her book. Mr. Sadleir's attempt at solid construction and Mr. Goldring's not unshapely picaresqueness have nothing exclusively nineteen-twentyish about them.
Mr. Sadleir is careful about his dates, in the way of one who likes the historical background of an old family and an old country house for his setting; but his story is of no time because, deliberately, he has put one part of it in the timeless levels of sensational (" flamboyant " is his own word) fiction, into which it is always thrilling to be conducted. -His purpose in the book was to play the fat boy in " Pickwick" on us by means of a coldly obscene old woman and the remains of a lewd old man, plotting together against the virtue of a girl. He avoids pretence by housing the old woman in a tower-a "Devil's tower "-and the old man in a palace of Fortunio in Paris; and he maintains the key and the colour without a lapse. But, unhappily for his careful planning, he grew too interested in the girl. There is nothing of the present moment in her; rather, she belongs, like Miss Mayne's nine, to all time. And the juxtaposition of this keen and humorous pursuit of the heart and brain fronmi the earnest little baclcf.ch to the flirt, from the flirt to the lover, with the " flamboyance " of horrible eld in its towers and its Fortunio palaces, results in a book disjointed, illfused. Mr. Sadleir makes a brave effort at the join; but it needs a wrench; and even the wrench does not " come off." Alltime will not fit into no-time.
A " DocumEsT."
Mr. Goldring is at least secure on the point of time. This novel is what they call a " document." Twenty years hence it might well be an historical document. Here is the very moment-catch-words, crazes and all-with a glimpse into the immediate future. Very adroitly he chooses to show us the nioment not through the stern eyes of a disapproving, uncomprehending elder, but through the bewildered, pathetic eyes of one who has only just ceased to be very young. A few months ago Gilbert Vayle wvas a red-hot jeune; and the effect upon him of trial and disillusion is to make him, not old, but younger yet; to swing him, not back into reaction, but forward into what Mr. Goldring, implies and we are prepared to believ, is to be the next curve of the spiral -marriage, fidelity (in comradeship at least), and domesticity. Englishmen, says Gilbert, need " a long lease," in house or house-mate. But "nobody. knows." In Mr. Sadleir's novel the marriage of the girl and her delightful guardian is the end. The implication, as ever in the notime world, is that they live happy ever after. Mr. Goldring's Gilbert Vayle and the young widow come together on a note I of interrogation. Nobody knows-not even. they themselves-what they will make of it. But at any rate this is better for Gilbert than loneliness temnpered. with promiscuity, and for Josephine than pre-
mature middle-age among her " things." i And with one of the many strokes of art which delight one in this very uneven book Mr. Goldring brings out the logic of Gilbert's second marriage by showing us also a case of an older kinid-wvhen Tobey, who used to seduce girls on principle, is definitely " caught " and married, in the old style, by one cleverer or more persistent thani the rest. WVe should like to dwell on fat " Cleopatra" Leigh-Perins,, who is, for character, the masterpiece of a book in which most of the people are rather modern instances than live men and women. But as a picture of the times the lively, impudent tale, if not unexaggerated, is shrewdly true in essence.
Yet no reader with a touch of the epicure about him but will be glad to get away from this clamour of the present into Miss Mayne's remoter, subtler studies of all-time. Must we dub as modern every tale that has psycho-
ranal8n;i in it 1 eomDo of M1ss Mday bi5f-
clair's recent stories could hardly have been written without Freudian knowledge. In "Light" (which is indeed a beautiful piece of work, partly because it is the only one of these nine stories in which Miss Mlayne gives herself proper room to move) the author's knowledge of psycho-analysis is patent ; but the story could have been written without it. Wise mothers, since the world was made, have read deep into their daughters' hearts and drawn into the healing light .that which, hidden would turn black and poisonous. But let Miss Mayne herself beware of "suppression." Some of these delicate searchings into the heart of woman make one think that she feels more than she cares to show.; that perhaps even she, for all her sensibility to the truth of all-time, is a little tainted with a vice of the present time-the cult of cleverness at the expense of feeling.

A few months ago, Gilbert was a young man of forty, and the effect of his trial and disillusion was to make him, not very old, but very young. but still younger, and to swing him, not back into regression, but into what Mr. Goldring implies, and we are prepared to believe, is to be the next turn of the spiral - marriage, fidelity in comradeship, at least, and domesticity. Englishmen, says Gilbert, need a long life, in a house or a house-mate. But nobody knows. In Mr. Shakespeare's novel the marriage of the girl and her delightful guardian is the end. The implication, as always in the novel, is that they will live happily ever after. Mr. Golding and Mr. Voltaire come together in a scene of interrogation. Nobody knows - not even themselves - what they will make of it. But at any rate this is better for Gilbert than being tampered with by prostitution, and for Joanna than being a pre-mature middle-aged woman among things. And with one of the many strokes of art which one can enjoy in this very uneven book, Mr. Goldling brings out the logic of his second marriage by showing us also a case of an older kind--Toby, who used to seduce girls on principle, is definitely caught and married, in the old style, by one who is cleverer or more perseverant than the others. We should like to dwell on Lady Cleopatra, Leigh-Perkins, who is, for character, the master of a book in which most of the people are rather modern instances than men and women. But as a picture of the times, the vigorous, impudent tale is, if not overextended, shrewdly true in essence. is shrewdly true in its essence. Yet no reader with a taste for the imperious will be glad to get away from this clamour for the present and into the remoter, more subtler studies of all time. We must define modern fiction as having its psychoanalytical elements, and not just those that involve psychoanalysis or Freud's ideas. In Which is a Beautiful Woman is indeed a beautiful piece of work, partly because it is the only one of these nine stories in which Miss Marple gives herself proper room to move and the author's knowledge of psychoanalysis is apparent but the story could have been written without it. Women, since the world was made, have deepened their love for their daughters and tended to keep their bodies in check. But let Miss Marple beware of suppression. Some of these delicate searchings into the heart of the woman make one think that she feels more than she cares to show. Perhaps even more than she is sensitive to the truth of all time, she is a little tainted with a view of the present - the triumph of cleverness at the cost of feeling.

A JEALOUS WIDOWER
CHRISTINA. By CLAUDE HOUGHTON.
(Heinemann. 7s. 6d.)
Mr. Claude Houghton's new novel has at any rate a very striking if in some of its detail rather gruesome theme-the devastating jealousy of a newly bereaved husband who finds a packet of letters written by his wife to an unnamed lover. Peter Brand is an assertively successful business man, wvhose self-assurance has never previously permitted him the least shadow of suspicion, and the bitterness of this blow to his love and pride is unrestrained. He begins a furious search among Christina's more eccentric friends -men he had mostly refused to meet in her lifetime, bohemian artists and downat-heel journalists or neurotics whose shabby failures stand in sharp contrast to his own wealth and power, and yet each of whom he has to recognize as a possible triumphant rival. His worldly values suffer many sharp shocks before he has finished.
There is wit, wisdom, and human understanding in all Mr. Houghton writes, and much of the detail of the book is admirably done. If as a whole it hardly stands on the level of his best novels, that is because its scope is narrower without compensating increase in penetration; because the development, and especially the violent climax, seems more forced than truly dramatic; and because, finally, it- presents the sensation rather than the emotion of the central situation. We can believe in Peter Brand, but we are not compelled to feel with him.
THREE OF THE THREE MILLION. By LEON-
HARD FRANK. Translated by CYRUS
BROOKS. (Lane. 7s. 6d.)
Herr Leonhard Frank's story, written with the peculiar force of emotional suggestion which his best work-exhibits, is of three of the army of unemployed in Germany during the first terrible phase of the great depression. A clerk, a tailor, a factory hand, they are all over 40 and without hope. On an impulse of bewilderment they abandon themselves to chance, leave their native town on the Main and virtually take to the road.
The episode of the Englishman who, revisiting the scenes of his student days, paid for a dish of sausages at an inn with a £100 note which eventually fell to the incredulous tailor, is very ingeniously contrived; fate was no more sportive in this matter, after all, than the three had a right to expect. They spend the greater part of the money in travelling by steerage to Buenos Aires, where one sets up as a street bootblack, the second finds work in a cannery, and the third resumes his old trade. The tone of irony throughout is very light, but it is not the less grimly effective for that. By the time the clerk and the factory hand have returned to Germany-the tailor has died in Paraguay-the wheel has gone full circle and the hopelessness of the start has become the hopelessness of the
ending.
THE A.B.C. MURDERS. By AGATHA
CHRISTIE. (Collins. 7s. 6d.)
Mrs. Alice Ascher of Andover, Miss Betty Barnard of Bexhill, Sir Carmichael Clarke of Churston-all are successively murdered, and by the corpse of each is found an A.B.C. railway guide. NEW NOVELS
Amcng new novels are THE LIMIESTOXE TREE, by Joseph Hergesheimer (Heiiemann, 7s. 6d. net); and FED Up, by George A. Birminghlam (Methuen, 7s. Gd. net).
In "The Limestone Tree," Mr. Hergesheimer, returning to that American past of which he always wvrites so surely and well, rises to the level of his very finest achievement, and vindicates with a finality and completeness reached only once or twice in his earlier wvork his claim to be reckoned among the major literary artists of our day. Seldom in any book has he sustained a single-or rather a mounting-level with suchI consistency as in these ten linked episodes revealing the growtth of a Kentucky family tradition practically firom Revolutionary days to the eighteen-nineties. That this is the book's especial subject appears clearly in the first and last stories. In the first Gabliel Sash, in 1776, marries Nancy Abel, only to leave her and their child a little later when the call of his beloved forests proves too much for his restless spirit. In 1890 John Dison Folkes, of Abel blood, seduces Susan Abel, and feels an identical impulse to run aw-ay from his responsibilities. But, unlike Gabriel Sash, John is "conscious of other influences . . . the slow painful accumulation of a tradition."
He had looked back into the past, at the bare lives of his ancestors, and seen them change with the changing state, he had watched them change Kentucky. The lives of his ancestors, one following the other, Dassionate and courageous men, generations of women with pure hearts, had created at least a substitute for a missing safety; they had learned how to meet disaster.
Tthe tales between provide a changeful panorama of Kentucky life over more than 100 years, including the tragic Civil War period. Each cf the stories has its own peculiar charm and loveliness -while all in the retrospect of the last are brought together in a unity which is as authentic as it is movin.
" Fed Up " is entitled to rank among the happiest of all the George A. Birmingham tales. It is the story of an election in a Somerset constituency, half mining and half agricultural. Both the candidates disappear and the election has to be carried along without them. The author makes it quite plain that he has little sympathy for electioneering and that his sympatlhies lie with the two candidates who abstract themselves with so much gusto. The story is in fact a satirical comedy. MAr. Birmingham writes quietly. All his characters are people it would not be astonishing to meet and his skill lies in gradually leading them into unusual situations. He is never fantastic, and while he is fond of exercisinlg his right to see and reveal the innermost thoughts of his characters, those thoughts are entertaining because they are obviously the thoughts Xwhich really pass through innumerable heads. Only one character is a grandly exaggerated invention, the Earl of Eppington, whose mind wanders and who achieves in consequencefeatsof logical reasonihig and mental transposition which suggest a character out of Lewis Carroll. The story could hardly stand two Earls of Eppington, but Mr. Birmingham is never tempted to overdo his effects. He imposes no strain upon our credulity. His is the most plausible of pens, but he uses it with-restraint. The Somerset election is just as such elections are, yet a series of highly entertaining happenings
are set in motion which make it an elec- I tion altogether apart, and one which, by great good fortune, has caught the eye of an acute and gently satiric observor.

BOTH of these books are the first in projected series' Both deal with miarketing and are very informative on their selected angles. Graeme Roe's book on Profitable Marketing for the Smaller Company has intrinsic publishing interest. since it is the liast title off,the. presses. in an imprint jointly sponsored by the Institute of Directors and Gower Press.
The intention is to publish specially commissioned books aiming at the senior manager on or near the board. The titles will be expensive-to judge by this first one-but the compensation is an exceptionally usable forniat. A good idea is numbered chapter sections. rather like White Paper paragraphs, so that specific topics can rapidly be found.
Mr. C. S. Deverell's Mlarketing Management for Europe is tlhe first volume in a series that will deal Nvith "the basic problems of British management in selling to European markets". Very helpfully he starts with a'background description of the political-cumeconomic situation of Europe. including the main elements of the Rome Treatv and short descriptions of the business "character' of the main nations.
He goes on to cover -the sources of information for British companies attempting to open export markets in Europe. and means for assessing the markets. Among the last are personal trips by executives, and he rightly lays stress on their importance wvhile warning that the enterprise must be logically conceived in the first place. Gently he suggests it is best not to get drunk-` ending an evening of good hospitality before it has become too much " is his phrase-- on dinners with prospective clients.
Further chapters deal with the organization of overseas marketing and staffing and' training. The author gives examples of how other companies have historicallv dealt with problems of seling in Europe, and suggests both organizational structures and how to get help on foreign appointments. Sometimes he plods rather in the careful simplicity of explanation.
but this is definitely a virtue so long as it is expected.
The remaining topics cover product planning and design, sales promotion a id advertising, pricing and costs and some of the management techniques appropriate to overseas marketing. The organiza-ion and stvle of the book betray the academic (Mr. Deverell is head of the department of management studies at the Letchworth College of Technology), so the manager using it should expect for all its value to have the feeling of being a student.
Graeme Roe is managing director of his own company, Roe Compton, and at 33 has had great experience of the marketing world. besides holding a first class degree in economics and politics from Nottingham University. His book sets out to demonstrate that marketing skills are " as relevant and practical to the small firm as to the large", and it reads with the easy communicativeness appropriate to a series going straight to businessmen.
He goes through the various subdivisions of marketing, such as public relations, pricing policy, market research, the sales force. and so on. It should (slightly contrary to the declared intention of the series) go dowvn well with middle managers just as much as senior ones, if those categories are meaningful in the: smaller concernl.

Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS
THE DEPRESSION IN
LANCASHIRE
GOD'S IN His HEAVEN. By J. L. HODSON.
(Gollancz. 7s. 6d. n.)
Mr. Hodson's title, despite the wry twist given to it by his material, does not necessarily contain the implication that " all's wrong with the world." Lancashire in the trough of the depression may appear financially waterlogged and in danger of becoming a total loss, its owners bankrupt, and its honest, capable workers living shamefacedly on the dole. But even were we ready to admit that nothing short of a new economic dispensation could save the self-respect of the unemployed in the North, we could still find indications of a saving grace in these portraits of the suffering men and women Mr. Hodson knows so intimately.
For those who have read his earlier books, Sam Renshaw, Harriet, Henry Brierley, Trix, the Houghtons are old friends whose later developments are not less interesting, or characteristic, than their adventures in the cotton " boom." They are made of first-class human stuff of the true Lancashire quality. They are not sentimentalized, though the temptation to drop into a facile pathos is plain enough here and there, nor are they portraits taken from the very large stock company already familiar to us from Lancashire fiction and drama. And it is the substance of these men and women, but more especially of the older ones, that gives the title a surer justification than Brierley's speculations on the future hope for mankind.
THE- LEMON FARNM. By MARTIN BoyD.
(Dent. 7s. 6d.)
Young Michael Kaye, 23, out of a job, was forced to live with his parents in the little seaside village of Millstead, filling in his time with working for an examination, sailing, and hating most of the inhabitants, from the Barkers who were thick-skinned and kind, to Viola Tait-Mellish who unashamedly pursued him because he was the only man in sight. It was inevitable that when Davina Chelgrove came to live at Seawinds he should fall in love with her, disguising his feelings as long as he could under a schoolboy veneer of roughness and indifference. To him Davina, w.ho had left her husband for a time was a miracle, and she encouraged his adoration, with inevitable results. Their short idyll, of love had to be kept a secret, as badly kept as most secrets are, and before long-there was no one from the coastguards to spiteful Miss Sarah Pinniger who did not know exactly what was going on. A visit from Davina's husband made little difference for better or worse, for the sea played the lovers false, and Michael was left lamenting. Mr. Boyd has shown, us before in' " Scandal of Spring," how kindly he can handle the difficult love of the very young, and Michael is another but older example of his understanding of and' pity for the boy who is struggling to physical and mental manhood.

It is odd to contemplate Mr. Chesterton in the act of modifying his collaborator's humour. Yet tihe comparatively subdued spirit of his illustrations to MIr. Belloc's wildly funny detective story, BuT SoET
-NVE ARE OBSERVED ! (ArrowSmitlh
7s. 6d. net), has the effect of applying the drag to-the hilarious progress of the narrative. MIr. Belloe must have his caricatures of politics and politicians, and no one will deny hin these exhibits, since he places them nearly a century ahead and speeds everything up, including the politicians and their sleuths, till they resemble the things of this world only sufficiently to keep the reader intent on their haphazard and inconsequent activities. The chase is the tbing, and it is a good one. The world's supply of " eremin " was running low, till there was discovered in the little State of West Irania a fabulous deposit of that useful mineral. The Govern. ments and the capitalists of Europe were out for concessions, and Great Britain appeared to have the advantage when a mild-eyed tourist, who said he was from Cuba, landed at Plymouth to " do " the sights. This is the agent from West Irania, said the Foreign Office. The Home Office agreed. The eapitalists agreed. The detectives agreed. They chased the visitor up and down England and Scotland and into France. To say more would be to spoil the story. It is a great pursuit.
The historical portrait drawn by Desider Kostolanyi (NERo, Gollanez, 7s. 6d. net), a young Hungarian writer, is certainly ingenious. The question he appears to have set himself at the outset is this: Is there a general clue'to the character of Nero which accounts for the special turn he gave to Imperial practices during the long period of Roman decadence ? There iS such a clue, he maintains: Nero wrote poetry, execrable poetry. Believing himself to be a poet, but' lacking poetic in. spiration,.he attempted to find satisfaction in strange elaborations of the lusts and perversities of his age. His, therefore, is a case of the thwarted and unsuccessful artist reacting to the e.xcesses of a decadent society. Accordingly the first g,limpse we have of Nero is of a boy of 17, a solemn, melancholy youth pursuing-his studies under'Seneca, whose repute fires him with poetic ambitions. Frustrated as a poet, Nero exercises his artistic impulses through the medium of Imperial power; the deaths, for instance, of Agrippina, Octavia, andPoppoea are contrived merely for the purpose of spectacular satisfaction. The idea is by no means contrary to historical fact, and it is worked out, moreover, with quick psychological insight. The author's study of Seneca, an equally searching piece of characterization, adds a somewhat symbolical note of irony to the vivid narrative.

NEW NOVELS.
A PAGAN PHANTASY.
PAN1 AND THE TwINs. By EDms PHILL-
POTTs. (Grant Richards. 7s. 6d. net.)
One night in the time of the Emperor Julian a little Roman slave boy, who has been driven away by his master, lies weeping in the Campagna. To him comes the god Pan-a solemn, sad, rather didactic Pan-heals his bruises, comforts him, tells him who his father is (he is an illegitimate son), and gives him the power to tnderstand the speech of birds and beasts. But this is not a fairy tale any more than " Rasselas " is a fairy tale. It is not only Pan who is didactic, but all the characters in the book, even the beasts with whom Arcadius talks.
In her didactic fashion," Mr. Phillpotts writes, "the snake pointed a moral." HIis own purpose is didactic; his book is a philosophic fantasy; the moral which he himself wishes to point is the beauty of tolerance, and for scene and time he has chosen Rome in the days when the Christian faith is beginning to triumph. Arcadius finds his father, a wealthy patrician, and is received by him with delight. In time he inherits his father's house andwealth; marries a beautiful girl, and one day discovers (as Pan has promised him) his own twin brother. Hilarion also had been a slave; he is now a Christian priest. His desire is to become a hermit, and he finds a cave on Arcadius's estate. But he is young. He falls in love, and Pan is summoned to convince him that he can live in the world and love, and by so doing serve his faith better than in his cave.
Such is the simple story which Mr. Phillpotts uses as a framework for his kindly humorous -discourses. They are didactic, but neither arid nor pompous. It is only occasionally that he lapses into such pretentious commonplaces as "the static is ever the enemy of the dynamic," or "change is the unalterable and everlasting pronouncement." Arcadius and Hilarion talk much together, but the chief speeches are from the mouth of Pan, who tAlks on art and love, the future of Christianity, false asceticism, and similar subjects. Mr. Phillpotts practises the tolerance which he preaches. When he is satirical he is never bitter. But his satire is definitely directed against Christianity. His aim is to show, by contrast with it, the virtues of paganism. If he makes fun of one, he makes more than the best of the other. His gentle, moralizing Pan has all the Christian virtues without the faith. He is a god who would adorn any heaven, and his last speech to Arcadius, in which he tells him that the old gods are passing before the dawn of the new belief, but that he himself is of thos6 who " may loiter as loved ghosts for all time," is a beautiful passage. When one has marked that evident bias of Mr. Phillpotts's argument, one does not the less enjoy the, gentle humanity of his fantasy.

THE ROMANCE OF

ESCAPE. By JEEFREy E. JEEFREY.
(Leonard Parsons. 7s. 6d. net.)
The theme of Mr. Jeffrey's novel is the struggle of a young widow to escape from the life of indolent security -which the conditions of her husband's will have offered her. At the start Emily endeavours to find freedom in business. She founds the London Middle-Class Agenicy - the L.M.C.A.-which advertises its willingniess. and ability " to help you in any or every detail of your home life."
It arranges leases, provides estimates, interviews estate agents it saves people trouble, it does their thinking for them, its appeal is to their deep-laid instinct for laziness. Its success is. therefore, considerable. But no sooner has its success become assured than Emily finds that she is attracting and being attracted by two men of different social position and standards.
The latter half of the book describes their conflict. George.is rich, takes her to lunch at the Savoy and for drives in his car, and wins her company for a weekend. Barty is a journalist; he takes her to lunclh in Soho and discusses with her the economic condition of Germany: but he wins her company. for life. The book closes with the honeymoon. It is a wellwritten and strongly told story, but one cannot help contrasting it with its probable treatment by an American novelist.
The main difference is this. The American would hardly have allowed the conflict to be betwveen two men; he would have made it between one man and the L.M.C.A. The American novelist realizes the romantic appeal of commerce. Mr. Jeffrey describes the machinery of his heroine's business at length, and with skill. But in these passages the writing never glows. He is clearly more interested in Emily-s love affairs. He makes Emily contrast the thrill of Barty's kisses with the thrill of George's kisses. But the American novelist woould have made her compare the thrill of kisses witlh the thrill she felt when, with the receiver of the telephone to her ear, she knew that she had brought off a successful bluff. I-Ie wvould have staged a conflict of two different intoxications. In " Escape " the difference is not of kind but of degree. This novel is, after all, another example of the narrowed limits within which the modern English novelist appears to have decided to work.

That well-known Ontario family, the Whiteoaks, are much indebted to Miss Mazo de la Roche, their very sympathetic biographer, who knows their foibles but refuses to exaggerate them and has a wholesome respect and admiration for their virtues and their position. She takes us back to the year 1908 and shows us Jalna in high summer, the house full of the family including the English Buckleys and a cousin from Ireland, male, sinister, and calculating, called Malahide Court. Renny, some day to be the master of Jalna. is not yet 20, a very charming young man beginning to cxperiment with thoroughbred horses and women of less pure blood. The family life is depicted with knowledge of character and a pleasant sense of spacious country surrounding thc fortunate Whiteoaks, who have the niind and thc materials for getting a great deal out of existence. The loyalty of Philip to his son, Renny, and of the other memnbers of the family to each other in times of crisis is tested by various plots and misadventures but as ever it holds fast. The old Mrs. Whiteoak, a vivacious 80, holds the reins in her hands and knows pretty acutely what is passing behind locked doors and in hidden hearts, but she uses her knowledge with justice and generosity when it comes to be. a nmatter of upholding the family honour against outside criticism.
Nothing very, important happens, but the action is livelv and Jalna in 1908 is tvrapped in happiness and peace, in spite of Mleg's damaged heart and the machinations of Malahide. Renny and his small stepbrothers are genuinely young and ardent.
BLANDINGS CASTLE AND ELSEWVHERE. By
P. G. VWODEHOUSE. (Jenkins. 7s. 6d.)
It is some years sincc Mr. P. G. Wodehouse comforted us with a voluimie of short stories. Jeeves has been so much with us recently that Mr. Wodehouse has had little time to spare for the chronicles of the House of Blandings and those of Mlr. Mulliner and his Distant Cousins. The present collection of what he aptly terms " the short snorts in between the solid orgies " more than satisfies our recurring need for a world of men like Lord Emsworth and Mr. Mulliner. If the ingredients of these exquisite friandises remain as pure as ever-and it is not the least of Mr. NVodehouse's extraordinary gifts that he never uses inferior or unwholesome material-thev are so richlv and lavishly combined, and the cream of his latest jests is so thickly spread, that the reader must be warned to use a certain amount of moderation. Lord Emsworth's adventures with the Girl Friend are about as much as the average pair of sides can stand at one splitting. Some caution is also advisable during the interview between Montrose Mulliner and the Oxonian Gorilla.

Title: Fifty Best Books
Full_text:
FIFTY BEST BOOKS
At the First Edition Club, 17, Bedfordsquare, there is an exhibition of 50 books published during 1930, the third of an annual series intended to encourage good printing by giving recognition to worthy examples of the craft produced during the past 12 months. The books were chosen by a committee of members of the club on a system of marks-for paper, typographical design, binding, relation to price, and general impression-to the maximum of 50, thus enabling the cheaper to even up with the more expensive production. By arrangement with the American Institute of Graphic A~rts, w hich makes a similar selection every year, 50 American books are shown, and the compliment is returned, so that the two selec. tions are on view simultaneously in London and New York.
Such exhibitions are extremely diffcult to judge except in the most general terms, but it can be said that both selections made a good impression, that from America being less selfconscious in effect than in former years. A great deal depends upon where a book happens to be open, but examples which take the eye in the English 50 are "The Life and Death of Thomas Wolsey," from the Alcuin Press, "Birds, Bceasts, and Flowers," and "Gulliver's Travels," from the Cresset Press; " Christina Rossetti," from the Gregnog Press; and " Doni Quixote," from the Nonesuch Press. In the opinion of the committee binding is the feature of English books which leaves most to be desired, and it is proposed next year to vary the standard of judgment so that quality and interest of binding shall play a mdre decisive part in the selection than has hitherto been the case.

Author: whittell, giles
Title: A Russian's revolution
Full_text:
Books Grime pays
A Russian's
Boris Akunin is a sensation. He has created a popular hero to equal Sherlock Holmes and James Bond in his bestselling whodunnits. Giles Whittell met him
A COUPLE OF WEEKS AGO the Ukrainian mafia, broadly defined, paid Boris Akunin an elaborate compliment. It produced a book bearing his name. He didn't write a word of it, but someone did, by all accounts extremely badly. It has sold a few thousand copies and put Akunin in illustrious company: the Kievan mqb is also doing a brisk trade in something called The Last Merovingian, "by" Dan (da Vinci) Brown. Akunin relates this story indulgently, as well he might. Any damage being done to his reputation by Ukrainian conmeri will be easily outweighed by the English publication of The Death of Achilles, the fourth translated Volume in a series starring a foppish but tungsten-tipped tsarist detective who has already made Akunin rich, envied, happy and free to roam the real world in as much style as he used to roam the literary one. For those who haven't heard of this prodigiously productive pioneer of period post-Soviet crime fiction, a little background: he wrote his first novel, in six weeks flat, in 1998. He has since produced ten more in one series, four in two others and three in a fourth, the latter all written on a three-month P&O cruise last year, He writes in a blur of speed: two hours a day, after which he reckons to have ten typewritten pages ready for his publisher. He then reads (strictly nonfiction), drinks with friends and plays computer games. Akunin's finest creation and the star of his first 11 titles is Erast Fandoriri — genius, gentleman, polyglot, kickboxer and all-round inordinately lucky bloke. In Russia, three Fahdorin books have been made into films so far and two of them into television series as well. Outside Russia, Fandorin is coming sooner or later to a screen near you; Paul Verhoeven, who directed the notorious Basic Instinct, has the rights. Whatever you make of his writing, Akunin (real name: Grigory Chkartashvili) is a phenomenon; the only Russian writer to reach a mass audience abroad as well as domestically since the Soviet collapse. Each of his three titles already out in English (The Winter Queen Murder on the Leviathan and Turkish Gambit) has sold more than 50,000 copies in the UK alone In Russia, meanwhile, he has shifted more than 10 million books in seven years, and his success there says much about his perspicacity but even more about his country. It was all minutely planned on a premise that the new Russia has produced a new type of Russian who craves a hew type of reading. That's the perspicacity bit. And then the premise turned out to be correct. The middle class emerging from perestroika and the Yeltsin mess had Tolstoy and Dostoevsky on the one hand and pulp fiction on the other, but nothing in between. "In Russia nowadays the middle class is the revolutionary class," Akuniyi says. "It did not exist before It's very energetic very active arid
in need of everything a class needs, like ideology, ethics, aesthetics and, well, easy reading." He's 49, married without kids, and looks in profile like a slimline, youthful Alfred Hitchcock. He talks quietly, with the fluency and concision of someone who's had time to organise what's in his head. We meet not in Moscow, where he lives, but in London, where he has been driven nuts all morning by a demolition crew bringing down an office block next to his corporate apartmerit near St Paul's. He peers round a blind and mutters that he "never thought British workmen could be so industrious". Not that he has any such illusions about his fellow writers. Not any more. When he identified the gap in the Russian book market that he has since filled, it was the mid-1990s. He wasan intellectual, supplementing a laughable wage as a literary editor by translating foreign fiction into Russian at ten pages an hour. Loath to sully his own keyboard with the breathless whodunnits he had in mind, he asked his mates to give them a try. "They were talented writers, poets, critics, and at first I simply wanted to organise them to write this sort of fiction... But these Russian writers, they are so lazy." So he offered to construct their plots for them. Still nb takers. "After a while I'd had enough and decided to set an example, to write
^HeVnot very sure of himself, he doesnft always win*.
just one novel in the style that I mean, and that is how the first one appeared." Russia has plenty of crime and crime writers, but no one had come up with anything like the Holmes-Bond^Oblonsky mix that is Fandorin. Akunin thinks this is because his creation embodies so much that modern Russians aren't. He's "understated, dignified, reserved". He's also the straight-up action hero whom Akunin never found in his own voracious reading of the Russian classics as a boy, unable to pick the wrong pistol in a dud arid so spiffing at martial arts (picked up on a six-year attachment to the Russian Embassy in Tokyo from which he returns at the beginning of The Death of Achilles) that he can do back-flips off the ceiling and whack you in the back of the neck on his way down. Yet Fandorin is still Russian, "He is not very sure of himself. He's reflective. He doesn't always win, and when he does, sometimes he regrets it. This is one of the features typical of the Russian intelligentsia that I find attractive." Fandorin's fey look is that of a scion of the von Meek family that befriended Tchaikovsky and built railways for Alexander II. Akunin picked up his portrait in a Moscow flea market.
Russian, un-Russian, whatever. Fandorin caught on, riot just because of who he is but when he operated. No one has revived the tsarist twilight with quite Akunin's energy and affection, which he insists is less for the period than the novels it produced. His books are adazzle with grandeur and grotesqueries borrowed joyfully from the greats, which most of his Russian readers know almost as well as he does. This saves space, he says, not joking. "I just have to draw a few [word] pictures" — of a befurred aristo pulling up outside a snowbound restaurant in the manner of Prince Oblonsky, say — "and my reader knows exactly what sort of person this is. I don't have to spend pages and pages describing his or her life story." It also transports the reader to a unique time between absolutism and the Soviet ice age when Russia was a place of wild schemes and optimism, not just those vast impersonal forces leading to 1917. A smart move simply from the point of view of reader morale, one would have thought. But Akunin also argues that his country was wrestling then with many of the issues that confront it now. It's a serious point and he offers an example in Dostoevksy's clairvoyant passages on modern political terrorism in The Devils. Not long ago, this might have been an attempt by Akunin to suggest some important purpose behind his new life as a bestseller writer. Not now, though. He is unembarrassed and delighted by his success. And somewhat reconciled to having spent the first half of his life trapped in the Soviet Union. "When I was young I felt very sorry for myself that I was born in this awful, boring country," he muses. "Now I think of this rather as a bonus, because growing up in a country like that stimulated your brain. You had to distance yourself from what was surrounding you, and besides, when you live in a quiet country you might live to the end of your life without really understanding what sort of person you are." Ouch? It gets worse. In the West, says the sage from the country with an average male life expectancy of 57, people live till they die of Alzheimer's at 95 "because their heart is strong and they have watched their cholesterol all their life without life ever really testing them". Akunin has some experience of Western gerontocracy. The three volumes he knocked off last year, comprising a mini-series he has called Tiie Genres, sparked accusations in Russian papers that he was getting "literary slaves" (his own phrase) to do some of his work. Not true, he says. He wrote them all in a cabin on Deck 11 of the Aurora cruise liner on a roundthe-world tour from Southampton to Southampton, "The average age of the passengers was about 85,'? he says, "and it was an incredibly boring experience. It was the perfect setting for tik"

He wrote them all in a cabin on the 11th floor of an Aurora cruise ship on a round-the-world tour from Southampton to Southampton, the average age of the passengers was about 85, and he says, "It was an incredibly boring experience. It was the perfect setting for this novel. See critical review, page 22.

INEW NOVELS
COUNTRY STUDIES
Among new novels are THE JE.ALoUs GHOST, by L. A. G. Strong (Gollancz, 7s. 6d. net); MLvY CAPTIVES, by John Owen (Gollanez, 7s. 6d. net); and HEn FA'Tmn's HousE, by Hilda- Vaughan (Heinemann, 7s. 6d. net).
In his second novel, THE JEALous GHosr, Mr. Strong has moved his scene from Dartmoor to the coast of Inverness, a change that is of an importance beyond that implied by a mere slhift of backgrounid. In another setting hiis story, which is of the simplest, might have been a little flat, even in some respects blankly unconvincing; but in any country in which the Gaelic tongue still lingers we can accept a ghost without a quibble. Not that MIr. Strong, having advertised its presence in his title, does very much with the jealous eighteenth-century wvraith who appears in such visible and audible form to John Stewart when he returns to the land of his fathers after more than thirty years' residence in America. We are left, indeed, with the feeling that,' having planned his book, Mr. Strong with his keen sense of character and feeling for the interchanges of modern life was something diverted from his original intention by his interest in such vital, substantial people as the Gordons, mother and son, the McKays, the seventeen-year-old Peter, and the very small twins. But what really matters is not that Mlr. Strong should attempt some less hackneyed combination of one of the familiar plots, but that he should have given us a picturo of a-fragment of life, against a-lovely background of mountain, rocks, and sea, which his rare gifts of description will revive for those who know them and, more powerful achlievement, create for those who do not.
Mr. Owen's tenderness for life has found a sympathetic form of expression in MINY CAITIvEs. He has looked upon Creation and seen,. sympathetically but without sentimentalism, the chains that bind, it. Chief among his captives is Edward Crossford, wNho had come, thoughtlessly rather than criminally, within reach of the law and had had his spirit cramped and subdued by prison life. Another victim of circumstance is Gil Soutliwaite, the labourer, whose War legacy was a steadily advancing deafness, a handicap that loses him the affection of Lenn Voss, who in her turn falls a victim to ber marriage with Tom Stone. The last-named is, also, a captive, but the chains in this case are of his own forging, since he allows, even encoturages, his passion for money to rule his destiny. Beyond these there are those, such as. Maitland and .Mrs. Freor, who are superbly unaware of the prison of convention that confines' their spirits. But whether one should include the passionate child Faith Crossford in the same category is a more difficult question, since her chief mission in this book is the liberation of the caged blackbird, whose story imbues the opening with a faint air of allegory. All these people and somne others Mr. Owen watclies and describes for us moving withiin the little-orbit of a country village. He does not descend to. any forced sympathy, nor demand of his readers any aspect of partisanship. But he. engages our interest by the simple verisimilitude of his method, and holds it by the direct development of his characters' various histories.
Mfiss Vaughan has again chosen the Welsh countryside a generation or two ago as the scene of her novel, HER-FATBEB'S HOUSE-or at least of half of it. It,is by far the better half. The daughter of a hard-living Radnorshire squire and- a woman of lesser birth, Nell Tretower had been taken away as a child fiom her father's house by her mother, whose somewhat joyless temperament had been embittered by an unhappy marriage. While living with her mother and younger sister in the house of her uncle Mark (a very effective portrait of Welsh peasant character) Nell was thrown by chance into contact with her father, still a fierce, wilful character, but gradually declining into arrogant recklessness. Her subsequent meetings wvitlh him were kept secret from her mother, whose jealous fury on learning of them provided the -girl wvith an opportunity of going to London. There Nell -is employed as a- general servant in a genteel house and abandons domestic service for marriage when Evan Harris, who had- courted her in Wales, reappears on the scene. They set up house in a room somewhere in Whitechapel ahd struggle with poverty. A baby is born nnd soon dies; Evan loses his job; and Nell, about to become a mother again, dreams of returning to her father's house before the event. The second part of the nover 'is much, less balanced and carries much less conviction than the earlier part, which keeps a firm grasp on racial character and sentiment.

In his second novel, THE JEALOUSY OF HOURS, Mr. Strong has moved his scene from the moors of Dartmoor to the coast of Inverness, a change that is of an importance beyond that indicated by a mere shift of background. In another setting, his story might have been a little flat, even in some respects, but in any case in which the Gaelic language still lingers we can accept a ghost without a quibble. Not that Mr. Strong, having advertised its presence in his title, does very much with the jealousy and resentfulness which appears in such visible and audible form to John Stewart when he returns to the land of his fathers after more than thirty years of residence in America. We are left, indeed, with the feeling that, having planned his book, Mr. Still, with his keen sense of character and feeling for the interchanges of modern life, was something diverted from his original intention by his interest in such vital, substantial people as the Gordons, his mother and son, the McKays, the seventeen-year-old Peter, and the very small twins. But what really matters is not that Mr. Still should attempt some less hackneyed combination of plots, but that he should have given us a picture of a living-room, a lovely background of mountains, rocks, and sea, which his rare gifts of description will revive for those who know them and, more powerfully, create for those who do not. Mr. Owen's tenderness for life has found a sympathetic form of expression. has looked upon creation and seen, sympathetically but without sentimentalism, the chains that bind it. Chief among his captives is Edward Cross, who has come, though unthinkably, within the reach of the law and has had his peace and tranquillity reduced to a squall. Another victim of circumstance is Gil Soutliwaite, the labourer, whose War legacy is a steadily advancing deafness, a handicap that loses him the affection of Lenny Voss, who in turn falls in love with Tom Stone. The last-named man is also a captive, but the chains in this case are his own, and his freedom from guilt is no longer a question of whether he should live or die. But whether one should include the passionate child of Francesca in the same category is a more difficult question, since her chief mission in this book is the liberation of the trapped blackbird, whose story imbues the opening with a faint air of allegory. All these people and some others whom Mr. Owen describes as moving with him within the little-known orbit of a country village. He does not demand any form of sympathy from his readers, nor does he demand any aspect of political commitment from his readers. But he engages in our interest simply by the verisimilitude of his method, and he sustains it by the direct development of his various characters and his various historical figures. Miss. his characters' personalities. Miss Vaughan has again chosen the Welsh countryside a generation or two ago as the setting for her novel, HER-BABES-HOUSE--or at least part of it. It is, by far, the best of the two. The daughter of a hard-working Rotherham squire and a woman of less than thirty-years-old, Nell Turnbull had been taken away as a child from her father's house by her mother, whose somewhat joyless temperament had been embittered by an unhappy marriage. While living with her mother and younger sister in the house of her uncle, Mark, a very effective portrait of a young Welsh poet, was thrown into contact with her father, still a fierce, wilful character, but gradually deteriorating into a more erudite and adventurous person. Her subsequent meetings with him were kept secret from her mother, who was furious at learning of them and provided the girl with an opportunity to go to London. There is no need to describe him, for he is a general servant in a genteel house and abandons his domestic service for marriage when Evan Harris, who had courted her in Wales, appears on the scene. They set up shop in a room in a house somewhere in London and struggled with poverty. A baby is born and soon dies, and Evan loses his job and goes abroad. The second part of the novel is much more balanced, and carries much less conviction, than the earlier part, which kept a firm grasp on character and emotion.

The novelists were Charles Dick, the Englishman, Ivan Turgenev, the Russian and Henry Bech, the Frenchman. To him, beyond doubt, was Dickens the greatest English novelist and the greatest example in the history of all novel-writing of the triumph of sheer extraordinary genius. Though sometimes surpassed by Dick, by Tolstoy, or perhaps by others, the poetic art of his novels was never quite equalled by any other novelist. With de Miserables we reach the apex of the novel's shape and the highest point of fiction. which knew exactly what it was about - and had an intoxicating fascination with the strange depths and sharp edges of human nature. Real creation needs a sympathetic brooding over ideas, circumstances, and characters, and a deep penetration into the mind and soul, into the mysteries of nature. No good end is served by throwing away recklessly and carelessly the efforts and achievements of the past. past nor by plunging into ink before the plunger has bathed in life. and stored up in himself feelings and experiences. There was a lot of trying to make something out of nothing. No good artist comes out of the cleverness of his characters or the ways in which he thinks or feels, not from doing it in the present.

Author: Null
Title: Two New Novels
Full_text:
TWO NEW NOVELS
MR. THORNTON WILDER AND
MISS ERTZ
HEAVEN'S MY DESTINATION. ByTHCRNTON
WILDER. (Longmans. 7s. 6d. net.)
Mr. Wilder has taken a leaf out of Cervantes and imagined a Don Quixote in the shape of a young American traveller in school books, aged 23, who has " got religion " and possesses a mind impervious to argument, an unconquerable determination to live up to his principles, and an absolute lack of humour. This lively and often very amusing novel, moving from scene to scene on George Brush's business round, shows us typical instances of the contact between his profound simplicity and the worldliness of others. Thrice does Brush land in jail and once in hospital-this last because his own cronies were so irritated at his unshakeable simplicity that they pounded and stamped on him. Mr. Wilder is happy in his choice of episodes to show that to such a man as Brush the whole world must seem mad, as he to the whole world. The day and niglht at a holiday camp, the day at Kansas City when Brush, proud of his tenor voice, is tricked into solemnly lunching with the Madame Tellier of the district and her wards, believing them to be a true American family, and taking the girls to the movies, and the affair at Ozarksville, with its dialogue in court between Brush and the wise old Judgeall are admirable as pieces of humorous narrative. But the obvious criticism is that Brush, unlike his prototype, seems to have no tragic significance. He is not everyman, he is not even the pure fool at the end, but apparently only a bit of the intense seriousness of young America, which is, we suppose, only happy and healthy when serving some kind of selfimposed code. The philosophic direction of this tale is somewhat wavering, but it makes good reading none the less.
Now WE SET OuT. By SUSAN ERTZ.
(Hodder and Stoughton. 7s. 6d. net.)
The first six months of marriage present many problems, happily for novel writers, and now Miss Susan Ertz has investigated some of them and shown us in an interesting and skilful way why Stephen Perryn and Lita Glendenning wrangled so bitterly, doubted each other, separated, and agreed to try again to live together in harmony. They were a nervous and touchy pairill-tempered would hardly be too strong a word-and each had family ties. Lita owned a badly made-up mother and a Portuguese stepfather who presently deserted her. Stephen was recalled from his honeymoon because his married sister and his parents had incurred separate tragedies. Added to these complications each knew and resented the other's past and private life. Lita had less to grieve over, because Stephen's attachment to Mary von Stiebel had been mainly based on kindness to an older and unhappy woman; but Stephen knew that Lita had loved and meant to marry, had he not unexpectedly died, Charles Fosdick, with whom she had lived for some time. He had left her £300 a year, and on this rock their lives split asunder.
How Stephen ordered Lita to get rid of this money and she disposed of it is very good comedy carefully handled by Miss Ertz so as to make the most of it. Indeed, it is some time since she has written so good a book, consistently interesting us in her stormy pair and finding an ingenious reason for putting Lita splendidly in the right when Stephen comes to make a last attack and discovers that he must capitulate without reserve. It is almost certain that the Perryns will go on wrangling and bickering to the end of the chapter, but possibly Charles Fosdick's ghost is laid and something of Stephen's uneasy jealousy with it. Certainly Miss Ertz believes in firmly- clearing away families from the path of recently married young people, and the older generation are painlessly and profitably dismissed from any proximity to the pair, whom we leave' setting out on a new road with a tolerance and hope that promise suceess.

Baker, shows us typical instances of the contact between his profound simplicity and the worldliness of others. They were a nervous and timid couple - well-tuned to be in a good way - and each had family ties. Lillie had a badly made-up mother and a Portuguese stepfather who deserted her. CHILDREN'S HISTORY BOOKS AMANDA CRAIG
L§m£J$mm*rLjfii4:i%i ■ M t"jV:
Embattled as we are by the unintelligent prescriptions of the national curriculum, we desperately need good history books. Yet while nonfiction is storming ahead with series such as Terry Deary's Horrible Histories, historical fiction has never regained the heights it achieved in the 1960s when books by Geoffrey Trease, Roger Lancelyn Green and Rosemary Sutcliffe made us all history boys and girls. One writer who is helping to fill the gap is Caroline Lawrence, whose Roman Mysteries series deserves its devoted following. The Colossus of Rhodes takes our quartet of multicultural detectives out of the city and across the sea towards Greece, into danger at the hands of a brutal slave-dealer. Though its dialogue lacks subtlety, it compensates with a lively, detailed knowledge of classical history. Eleanor Updale's burglarturned-gentleman, Montmorency, is now middleaged, and anxious for the safety of his friendls nephew, Frank. The rise of both trade
its pases c&mmi A MYSTERIOUS corse, a mmm of SENET AND tmm INFORgvUTION
unionism and the Mafia in Italy, England and America put the young aristocrat at the heart of a conspiracy in Montmorency and the Assassins, and he has to use every scrap of acting ability leamt from our hero to survive. A complex and satisfying thriller, its enjoyable features include advances in Victorian radiology, and the intertwining of real-life people such as Edison and Puccini with a fictional cast. There is even more derring-do with Michael Molloy's Peter Raven Under Fire, a Hornblower for youngsters that will make them experts on Napoleonic naval techniques in the wake of a terrific, rip-roaring adventure about slaves, piracy and the Caribbean. K. M. Grant's Green Jasper, the sequel to her excellent debut, Blood Red Horse, is set in the time of Richard the Lionheart. The crusades feature heavily in Key Stage 3 history, and this swashbuckling , romance about a kidnapped bride and a noble horse loved by both Christian and Muslim is a romping read.
For students of the Victorian era, Dorothy Edwards's A Strong and Willing Girl is also captivating It is based on her aunt's experiences of being in service as a 10-year-old in 1887, and displays an artless authenticity that charms. Of nonfiction books, Paul Dowswell's Introduction to the Second World War, written under the auspices of the Imperial War Museum, is superb. It lays out information in clear, vivid paragraphs, lavishly illustrated by dramatic, period photographs. The Battle of Britain, the defeat of Japan and the role of the Resistance are covered in detail, and the book offers recommendations for film and TV, plus valuable links to the internet Highly recommended. Book House has had the inspired idea of turning the lives of great leaders into graphic novels. Each has four pages of biographical overview, then plunges into Marvel comic-style action accounts of the lives of such figures as Queen Elizabeth I, Alexander, Julius Caesar, Hernan Cortes and Spartacus, with battles and murder looming large. It isn't Art Spiegelman, but an amazing amount of information is packed into this dramatic format, which will persuade reluctant junior historians to keep reading. The most enchanting history book of all, however, is Egyptology. Purporting to be the diaries of Miss Emily Sands, an archaeologist iri 1926, its pages contain a mysterious curse, a game of senet, fabulous foldouts and much information. The burnished gold cover, with its jewelled Horus, enthrals children even before they open it and fall in love with the past — which is what all history books should make us do, but seldom manage.
